reviewText: I usually don't review movies.  I stick to books.  However, with The Life of Pi, I am choosing to make an exception.  It is so darn good and so close to the book that I feel it deserves a review that reflects how wonderful it is.The Life of Pi is about and adult man named Pi who has a visitor in Canada who has met his uncle in India.  His uncle told the visitor that after speaking to Pi, he will believe in God.  Pi has a story to tell and he chooses to tell the story to the visitor who has the time to listen.Years ago, Pi's parents owned a zoo in India that started going bankrupt.  They decided to sell the zoo but take the animals to Canada and perhaps make a fresh start there.  The animals and Pi's family are loaded on a cheap ship like a poor man's Noah's Ark.  The animals are all tranquilized and kept in the basement of the ship so they won't get seasick.  A storm occurs and Pi and everyone else on the ship go overboard.  Pi finds himself on a lifeboat with a tiger named Richard Parker, a post-natal orangutang, and an injured zebra.  Together they start a stupendous journey through the Pacific waters.Most of the movie's renderings of Richard Parker were done by computer graphics and it's a mighty fine job they did.  We see how Pi and Richard Parker vie for space on the tiny boat and how, daily, Pi fears for his life as a tiger's meal.The movies has some strong philosophical and theological issues that play out beautifully and it is one of the best movies I have seen in a very long time.  I am very impressed at how close the movie is to the book.  Usually, I get very annoyed because movies and the books they are made from have very little in common.  Not so with The Life of Pi.  It is a beautiful book, a beautiful movie, and the two mesh together as one.I recommend that everyone see this movie.  I saw it in 3-D and that was quite an experience.  However, I get migraines and the 3-D was a bit overboard (no pun intended) for me.  Someone told me that the actor who played the young Pacine had never acted before.  If so, he is a natural, and a wonder to boot.There isn't a spare word in the movie, nor a spare scene.  It is beautiful, thoughtful, and we finish the movie asking ourselves whether God exists.
summary: The Book and The Movie Each Elevate One Another

reviewText: Director Ang Lee has created a visually stunning, highly evolved computer-generated, emotional masterpiece in his film "Life of Pi".But I must warn, this film is not for the faint of heart! It's NOT a cuddly children's movie about a boy and his tiger. I do not recommend this film to any young impressionable children. It is a tragic story of loss, survival and a struggle to cheat death at sea. Belief in God and religion are spoken of with heart-felt emotion and pain. Beautiful but possibly scary imagery of the sinking of a huge ship, sharks and scary fish at sea could cause young children nightmares. This is a captivating, chilling and powerful film. "CGI" animals are seen in extremely stressful situations and even die in this film.*While I viewed this film a nice family consisting of two parents with two young children were seated right in front of me. Not far into this film during a stressful zebra action scene, I witnessed the little girl (maybe about ten years old), jumping out of her seat crying running out of the auditorium with her mother hot on her trail. The father and small son were left behind. Soon, they too left never to return. So beware."Life of Pi" is also sad and extremely dramatic with excellent acting from it's entire cast but most notably that of Suraj Sharma. Wow, can this young man act! He carried almost all of this entire film acting against an invisible tiger. I think he should receive a best actor nomination for his wonderful job!Lady's bring lots of tissues in your purse because "Life of Pi" made me cry several times throughout it's two hours six minute running time.I thoroughly enjoyed this fine film! I do highly recommend "Life of Pi", but only for much older children and adults. Enjoy!Update: Golden Globes winner for Best Score.Academy Award Nominations: Best Picture, Best Director Ang Lee, Best Production Direction, Best Visual Effects, Best Song-Pi's Lullaby- by Mychael Danna and Bombay Jayashri, Best Cinematography, Best Sound Mixing, Best Film Editing, Best Sound Editing, Best Adapted Screenplay, and Best Original Score- composed by Mychael Danna.Update: Academy Award winner for Best Director, Ang Lee, Best Visual Effects, Best Cinematography and Best Original Score.Release date: 21 November 2012Running time: 120 minutesRated: PG ~ for emotional thematic content throughout, and scary action sequences and peril.Live-Action/Computer Animated/Adventure DramaGrade: B+
summary: This visually stunning masterpiece wins 4 Academy Awards!

reviewText: This film is appealing on many levels.  Many human characters are attractive in different ways, though the writer is only a foil, not even as developed as the interviewer in "Interview with the Vampire."  The central character, Pi, is so engrossing and the development of his life is so captivating that only his immediate family are relevant in the film.  Some animals are significant, but the Bengal Tiger embodies powerful forces of Nature with which we are obliged to become aware and learn to live with.  The trials that Pi has to go through speak to the common challenges of the human condition, but are exaggerated in ways that, thankfully, most of us don't have to experience.  They are illustrative of the human search for meaning and purpose, and for ethical and moral ways of being in the world.  The story has a smoothly coherent ending that leaves us with a warm glow, contentedly chewing a cud of psychological, philosophical, and spiritual questions and feeling ourselves worthy because of it.
summary: Warm, visually stunning, human story informed by meaning

reviewText: I'll probably get bashed for leaving this review by those who have read the book and who have a better understanding of the hidden meaning(s) in this movie. But I don't think a person's understanding of a film should be contingent on reading and completely grasping the novel prior.The special effects were dazzling in and of themselves but they were distracting to the overall story line. Jellyfish don't fluoresce to the point of creating a "glow stick" effect making everything visible in the middle of the night in the middle of the ocean. Meerkats don't live on some "bionic island" in the Pacific nor do they sleep in trees. They burrow in the ground and live in Africa. So many times the water was way too calm and it was obvious they were filming (several) segments in a pool and it was obviously synthetic.From other people's reviews it seems that the second story that involved real people was what really happened. But what felt so deflated was how so much attention and detail were devoted to the fantasy of story #1 that when the second story was told in a mere forty seconds - I felt so ripped off. Maybe a brief visual or some flashbacks capturing the violent/turbulent time with the human survivors might have made it more salvageable. It came off as poorly executed and something quickly tossed into the movie.For me this movie didn't make me ponder or embrace a higher power. This is what we're supposed to think simply because he survived a ship wreck? God spared him? What about the people in the supposed second story (what really happened) who didn't survive like his mother and the cook and sailor? If the story were told from their point of view we'd have a very depressing movie pondering that there is no god at all. Instead we are fed a sugar-coated, extravagant lie and now we're supposed to feel all warm and fuzzy inside. So much detail paid to fantasy and the animation and not nearly enough to details and to conveying a consistent and infallible message. Oh and that last scene with the Tiger slowly walking into the jungle as if to say, "See ya, wouldn't wanna be ya." left me totally flat. I expected too much, I guess.
summary: Amazing animation but confusing story line.

reviewText: Ang Lee is pretty damn amazing. Here is a Chinese filmaker with an ouvre that includes such varied work as Brokeback Mountain, Hulk, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, Eat Drink, Man Woman, Lust, Caution, and now Life of Pi (all except for Hulk pretty brilliant). That one man can capture both the unique Chinese flavor of Crouching Tiger and the Western American rhythm of Brokeback. Amazing.Now we have this film, which resists all categorization. At one level, it's an eminently watchable survival adventure and pure visual treat. I haven't read the book yet (I will now), but I have to asume it has a fable-like quality, and so does the film. The color alone is surreal and intense. The cinematography is gorgeous. Some of the shots... woah. There is some odd unreal nighttime lighting here too -- although it works. There is very heavy use of shallow depth of field to good effect.It's worth noting that I saw the film in 3D, which has clearly graduated from three years ago when it was only for the likes of Alice in Wonderland (hiss) and How to Train Your Dragon. Now we have it in high budget literary adventure religious allegory. Interestingly, I'm pretty convinced that 3D has the effect of decreasing realism. It makes everything look like CGI, heightened, super-real, like an HDR photograph.The acting is also superb. The casting of Pi at various ages is dead on. All three are highly emotive. And the tiger -- who is presumably 90% CGI -- he's the stuff of legend. There is one damn cool animal. The soggy cat hanging off the side of the boat is just so sad, lest us forget that the Bengal Tiger is the world's most dangerous land animal. Tiger's are fast, deadly, climb, swim, and can bat your head off with one paw. Imagine sharing a lifeboat with one! There's a 19th century tiger known to have killed over 430 men.The film is to beautiful, that the ocean itself, and its bevy of sea life, becomes a character. As desperate as Pi (and Richard Parker the Tiger) are, they can't help but marvel at the little seen wonders that present, and us with them.Thematically, I'm not yet sure how to digest Life of Pi. It's a pretty deeply emotional movie, and at some level plays to the film medium's visual strengths. The picture hints at deeper philosophical notes, but doesn't really illuminate. I sense extreme abbreviation. After all, 450 pages of novel would result in perhaps six hours of film.Andy Gavin, author of The Darkening Dream and Untimed

reviewText: Life of Pi may not have been the best film of 2012 (I think Lincoln was a better movie), but it was certainly one of the top couple of movies.  It's a gorgeous film with a great story.  I found the acting by the lead character believable and involving.  The 3D aspects of Life of Pi are subtle and probably make little difference in terms of the the story.  But it certainly has its moments of depth that enhance the beautiful cinematography.  While the film is memorable for the many scenes on the open sea with just Pi and Richard Parker (the tiger), the shots looking upward through the water in the clear-as-a-bell swimming pool are the images I think of most often.  Life of Pi is based on a book that was among my favorites when it came out several years ago, so I was prepared to be disappointed in the film.  I wasn't.  Ang Lee handled the material with great respect, and told the story quite well given the time limitations of a film vs. a book.  It's a movie I expect to watch many times and joyfully share with others.
summary: Great Adaptation of an Outstanding Book

reviewText: I hate to admit it but I have never read ` Life of Pi", I have come close many times to reading it but have never quite got around to finish it. In my opinion the book is quite unfilmable because there are many elements that exist in the book cannot be truly captured for the big screen, but after watching the film adaptation, I have to admit that Ang Lee has done a very good job.There is a shipwreck and Pi finds himself on a lifeboat with a Bengal tiger named Richard Parker.Spiritual questions about faith, meaning of life are the backbone of this film which has been created with the help of CGi. However the CGI is beautiful and drop dead gorgeous. The movie on the whole is very beautiful to watch- possibly the best looking movie in many years- the whale in the night, the scenes in Pondicherry, the Island crawling with meerkats, the squadrons of flying fish, the ocean and the supremely regal Richard Parker. This is a film that celebrates the lush beauty of visual cinema through state of the art CGI: Drop dead gorgeous. Claudio Miranda the cinematographer deserves an applause.

reviewText: For its technical accomplishments alone, Ang Lee's LIFE OF PI is likely to rank at the top of the list of 2012's best for many viewers, and there's no doubt from an artistic standpoint, its visuals were unmatched by any other film last year.An adaptation of Yann Martel's seemingly impenetrable rumination on the triumph of the human spirit, man's place in the universe, and the role of religion in an individual's spiritual journey, "Life of Pi" is, first and foremost, a film for the senses. Working from a script by David Magee, director Lee's film follows "Pi" Patel (Suraj Sharma), a young man who learns of different religions growing up in the Puducherry region of what was once French India. His inquisitive nature, both encouraged by his mother (Tabu) and discouraged by a father (Adil Hussain) who operates a zoo in their town, is scuttled as he grows older and his family is eventually forced to immigrate to Canada. En route, the Japanese freighter carrying them, as well as their zoo animals, is wrecked in a storm, with only Pi escaping - alongside a zebra, orangutan, hyena, and a Bengal tiger named Richard Parker, who journeys with Pi on an ocean teeming with both peril and wonder, with florescent jellyfish lighting up the world beneath them and humpback whales catapulting through the air."Life of Pi" is so staggeringly, jaw-droppingly beautiful that Lee and cinematographer Claudia Miranda's effective use of the 3-D format is evident from the movie's first frames. Long before Pi and Richard Parker set out on a lifeboat of individual discovery, "Life of Pi" has already captivated the viewer with its fascinating portrait of young Pi's life in French India, with gorgeous landscapes, colors and animals filling each and every frame. Most of the movies we see using 3-D employ it merely as a gimmick to goose grosses, but much like Martin Scorsese's "Hugo," Lee here frames so many sequences with depth-of-field dimension that its inclusion ranks as an absolute necessity to appreciating the spellbinding images that Lee and Miranda - both of whom were deservedly honored with Oscars, alongside composer Mychael Danna and the visual effects team at Rhythm & Hues - generated here.The film's story is another matter; one can easily see why readers of Martel's book were drawn to the material, for its mostly ambiguous, take-out-what-you-put-in take on world religion and faith, in general, functions mostly as a byproduct of the individual reader. On-screen, Lee is able to invest the material with a similar cloudiness, though that ambiguity is harder to achieve in a medium like film. There's no outright sermonizing in the picture, but its ending is more forcefully tilted in one direction than the more hazy conclusion Martel originally wrote. Still, however obvious (or not) the film's metaphorical messages and spiritual philosophizing happen to be, there's no question "Life of Pi" is a film that's impossible to forget and easy to appreciate on a sheer artistic level. Whether or not you find it to be as enriching an emotional journey will be - much like its source material - up to the individual viewer.Fox's 3-D Blu-Ray presentation of "Life of Pi" is unquestionably a must-view for any 3-D home theaterphile. The images, composition and clarity of the 3-D are spectacular throughout, and as I wrote before, few films have demanded viewing in the 3-D format more than "Life of Pi." The 3-D Blu-Ray also includes nearly 15 minutes of exclusive deleted scenes, plus the trailer in 3D and visual effects progressions (these exclusive extras can also be played in a standard BD player). Other supplements on the standard Blu (which features a dazzling 1080p AVC encoded transfer in its own right) boast several featurettes, an art gallery and storyboards, while a DVD and digital copy round out the disc. The DTS MA 7.1 audio is impressively mounted as well, highlighting another fine score written by Danna for his long-time cinematic collaborator.One final note on "Life of Pi": it's inconceivable to me that this picture generated a PG rating from the MPAA. With its marketing campaign dominated by images of Pi and the tiger together in the lifeboat, I have no doubt there were parents who took children to this film, only to be horrified by the animal violence that occurs in it - even if it's off-camera and isn't gratuitous, this isn't a film for young kids, and should've absolutely received a PG-13 for that and the generally intense tone of the picture. Of course, this isn't the first sign our ratings system is dysfunctional - merely the latest evidence of it.
summary: Gorgeous 3-D Visuals in a Unique, If Uneven, Viewing Experience

reviewText: I've given myself a few months to digest this film, since I feel as though my initial response to it may have been jilted thanks to my unapologetic adoration of the novel.  Jilted in a bad way, since I felt this paled in comparison and so I was almost angry at the film for being critically successful.  Taking these few months to let it all marinade, I have to admit that not a whole lot has changed from my initial feelings.While reading `Life of Pi', on a plane coming home from Europe, I was spellbound.  Page after page kept me intrigued and absorbed and engaged and completely in awe of everything being expressed and expounded on.  The journey and magical quality of it all was one thing, but the spiritual undertones and the way it beautifully developed the themes of faith and God were so articulate yet never condescending or overbearing that it all felt so effortless.  Up until that point, I had no real interest in the film adaptation that was fast approaching, but after putting the book down I was overcome with this intense desire to see Lee's film.  When I saw that it was a PG rated film, obviously directed at families, I was a bit hesitant.  It's not that the novel was extremely graphic, and yet in parts it really was and I just couldn't understand how you could try and make this a family film.Still, I had to see it.For those unfamiliar with the story, the basic premise is this.  A young boy named Pi (pronounced Pee) grows up in India on a zoo with his family.  At a young age he becomes fascinated with the idea of God and faith and religion and begins to study and practice multiple religions in an attempt to bring himself closer to God.  When his family decides to sell the zoo and move to Canada, Pi finds himself on a boat with a crew that dislikes him and a slew of animals in cages awaiting their destiny overseas.  During a terrible and unexpected storm everything goes awry, Pi's family is killed and he is left destitute on a life boat with a hyena, zebra, orangutan and Richard Parker, a Bengal tiger.  For 227 days, Pi has to learn to survive alongside this beast.It is an intriguing tale and one that it mostly approached from an angle of respect, and I must admit that the way Lee visually crafts the film is marvelous, but outside of those visuals I found the film to be almost shallow in its presentation of the more intimate and important themes of the story.  The core of the story is lost in a film that becomes redundant and superficial.  I think a big problem with the `translation' of the film is that the key segments on the book are all internalized.  You read the thought patterns of young Pi and you begin to become entranced in his world.  In film it isn't always easy to convey internalized transformations and so the outward redundancies (yelling at the tiger, starving, fishing, yelling at the tiger) carry less weight.  While there is tragedy at the center of the film, it became almost too focused on the visuals and so it lost the heaviness needed to carry the emotional side of the story.  It became pretty, but empty.  I also found the changes to the story to be unnecessary.  Pi's love interest was a ridiculous inclusion, especially since there is no development of that story and so their separation carries no weight.  I also found the whale scene to be kind of pointless, yet pretty, and while I understand the idea of creating tension thanks to the aftermath of the scene it just didn't do what it set out to do.The way the film is spliced is also somewhat irritating, although I'm sure it was developed to try and add some interruption to the redundancy of Pi's struggle.  The constant shifting from present to past and the use of Irrfan Khan (elder Pi) as a narrator for many of Pi's actions felt forced and took me out of the story, to be honest.  It also took some of the key moments in the book (like the adventure on Meerkat Island) and condensed them to the point where they were almost pointless.  I understand the need of narration to explain certain things that visuals won't readily explain, but these segments were so short that they almost trivialized their inclusion.I'll admit, the conclusion is still heartbreaking, and when the big question is asked, "Which story do you prefer?", I can't help but feel the lump in my throat.  I also can't help  but reply, "I prefer the story Yann Martel told me!".Still, `Life of Pi' is a beautiful film.  The visual effects are some of the best I've ever seen in a film, and for that it richly deserved its Oscar.  I take issue with the cinematography Oscar, since the skies and sea were all created by the visual effects department, but whatever.  This was purely a director's film in the end, and so for that I guess Lee's Oscar shouldn't be all that shocking to me, although I really don't think he deserved it.  He may have created a visually arresting film, but the core of this film was not a visual one but an emotional and spiritual one and he failed to tie those ends together (for me).Despite the heaviness of the actual prose, there is something `slight' about this interpretation.

reviewText: I just got through watching 2012’s “Life of Pi” for the second time around only this time in 3D.  Every year The Academy gives out my favorite award for “Best Cinematography” and it’s no wonder that Ang Lee’s “Life of Pi” won it.  The film is visual eye candy and breathtakingly sweet.  “Life of Pi” just pours on the visuals.  The 3D is the very best I have seen on any home transfer to date; razor sharp and incredibly crisp.My favorite scene was when Pi and Richard Parker land on the island of Meerkats.  Seeing Pi basking overhead in one of the island hotspots at nighttime was so beautifully rendered and with the added constellations and star-light the scene was sheer magical perfection.“Life of Pi” is a spectacular film that I will re-watch over and over again for many years to come.

reviewText: I saw Life of Pi in cinemas in 3D, and WOW!This is truly one of the most beautiful (visually and emotionally) movies of the year. Life of Pi almost equals The Hobbit in vivid, lush, gorgeous cinematography. Everything looks and feels magical! The CGI does nothing but accentuate the film. It accents the story and the human actors, without detracting of distracting from the film (Lucas...Cameron...I'm looking at you!)Yes, the story is hugely dumbed down for the film. This is my only con. Lee cuts out at least 45% of the book, including several storm sequences, a fight between Richard Parker and a Mako shark, another castaway that Pi happens upon, numerous brilliant philosophical musings, and quite a bit off the ending.If I had to choose between them, I would say I liked the book better. But it's impressive that Lee came as far as he did. I would NEVER have thought it possible to film Life of Pi, never!But that is not to detract from the visual magic, the beautiful cinematography, the ground-breaking CGI, the stellar acting (Suraj Sharma, kudos to you. You have a career ahead of you!). I loved Life of Pi. I saw it twice, and turned around the second time to watch the audiences faces during the infamous "jump scare".Strongest Recommendation for Life of Pi! 4.5 Stars!P.S. Is it coincidence that Life of Pi actually DOES contain a "Crouching Tiger"...and a hidden tiger?
summary: Life of Pi is a Stellar, Beautiful, Achievement!

reviewText: As a voracious reader, I feel the need to preface this review by saying that I have not read the book this film was based on. Not sure if I ever will, but there it is, I haven't. And thankfully it's not one of those "you HAVE to read the book to understand the movie" type of things. I thought the film started off slow, but it helped establish Pi's character rather than just toss him on a lifeboat with a tiger and wait to see what character development happens afterward. The reason for going by "Pi" was creative. And the telling of the story via flashbacks was a good choice; you got the sense that even so many years later, Pi still carries all of this with him every single day. The actors appeared very well cast in their roles -- I liked that Lee cast a lot of unknowns (or at least, unfamiliar to the Western world), because then you weren't distracted by preconceived notions of the actors' abilities and you could focus on the story the film was telling. Suraj Sharma did a particularly spectacular job, considering how his tiger companion was a character completely created in CGI. From a technical standpoint, Life of Pi deserved every Oscar it scored (Visual Effects, Director, Score, Cinematography). The score was subtle but stirring when it needed to be, and seemed to evoke more emotionally than the actors could, probably due to Pi's somewhat stagnant position on the lifeboat in the middle of the ocean. The night scene stands out to me as far as effects, score and cinematography are concerned because it just takes your breath away; between the infinite number of stars and the bright reflections of fish underwater to the breaching humpback, the entire scene was incredible to watch. And enough praise cannot be bestowed on the crew who worked to bring not just Richard Parker but all the other animals to life as well -- they all acted very realistically in regard to each other and to Pi himself. I have friends who've seen this film and thought it extremely boring -- maybe it's jsut me, but I can't understand how something so intriguing could bore someone. Broaden your mind with this film, it's a good one.
summary: Deserved every Academy Award it won

reviewText: It's been a long time since I read the book, but if memory serves me correctly it seems that this movie does a good job at staying true to the story.  The animation was good and realistic, so while you knew the animals weren't all real you didn't care because they were close enough.  The story told what it had to, did it well, and moved along at a pretty good pace.  All in all it was quite entertaining.If you're a Christian realize that you'll probably have to discuss with your kids the inherent difficulties of co-opting all religions into one, as the main character does.  His father tells him that believing in everything is much like believing in nothing, which is all too true but an issue that the main character never addresses.  But in the end the final message about faith in general is a good one.

reviewText: Ang Lee's "Life of Pi" is strikingly beautiful in many ways, from great cinematography to the story being portrayed.  You need to be prepared is half of the movie is graphics with music.  I will not take the time to compare and contrast this film with others as it is so unique in itself.I have to admit that I have not read the novel by Yann Martel and I am sure that a lot has been left out.  I will need to read the book to find out what was implied; unless of course the screenplay went off in a different direction.  You will want to watch this film over again after the shock value so that you can pick up the nuances that you missed while you were speculating on what was about to happen.The basic story is about a young man named Pi (Suraj Sharma) whose father owns a zoo.  Throughout his life Pi wonders about what Douglas Adams calls "life the universe and everything."  Because of business concerns his father packs up the zoo animals on a freighter setting out for Canada.  Due to a mishap Pi no longer has to speculate but actually lives "life the universe and everything."  We travel with them through his trials and tribulations wondering what we would do in that situation.One can come away from this film with a new insight or at least say that they saw a movie that was strikingly beautiful in many ways.

reviewText: This film is truly exceptional.  It is also very difficult.  I do not want to ruin the experience for you so I offer a few pieces of advice while watching and nothing more...1.  Keep an open mind.  There are many messages that are not fully revealed until the end.  This is made more difficult because these seemingly separate messages do tie in to a much broader message that is revealed almost simultaneously.2.  The VFX are spectacular but the film is not meant to be a spectacle.  There is meaning to be found in almost every component of the story.3.  When finished, research the story.  Specifically the names of characters and how they are related to actual historical events.4.  Enjoy and suspend disbelief...  This is a carefully nuanced piece of art intended to affect change in the viewer.It is my belief this story is intended to change the world.  Not that it actually will but the message is incredibly broad and idealistic.  Some people may find the message reassuring while others may find it disturbing.  What worries me is that in many ways this is art for artists.  It requires analysis and information beyond what is presented but that is part of it's beauty.
summary: A message for and about humanity...

reviewText: Why you shouldn't see it:Not to give away too much about this particular movie, but... it drags at parts. While it doesn't necessarily feel any longer than its two hour runtime, it does feel every minute of it. Have you ever watched a movie that takes place entirely on a lifeboat? Well, neither have I, but I've now seen half of a movie that takes place entirely on a lifeboat. I understand there's another movie - titled, coincidentally enough, Lifeboat - that takes place entirely on a lifeboat. Maybe someday I'll watch that Hitchcock piece, but until then I'll have to settle for this particular lifeboat-centric movie. Okay, okay, I have exaggerated slightly how much of this movie takes place on a lifeboat. The parts of the movie that take place on the lifeboat aren't technically entirely on the lifeboat, as there is also the 20-or-so-foot radius of open water around the lifeboat where some action also takes place. So there's that.This one actually reminds me a fair amount of Cast Away in that the majority of the movie leans heavily on the ability of a single character to engage the audience's interest while he does nothing more than try to survive in extraordinary circumstances. The problem with that comparison is that Suraj Sharma is no Tom Hanks (full disclosure: I have an almost creepy respect for Tom Hanks' acting chops, so I may be biased here). While the latter half of Cast Away thrives on Hanks' ability to make otherwise mundane onscreen moments incredibly intriguing, Life of Pi just doesn't have as strong a feature actor to revolve its survival story around.Strangely, some of the more dragging parts of the movie happen before Pi ever fatefully sets foot on a boat. Since the story isn't so much about a lifeboat as it is about a boy and the man that boy becomes, there's the sometimes regrettable necessity of building a backstory about where this person is coming from. It's hard to explain, but there is just something about this backstory that doesn't hold my attention nearly as well as others (for example, Cast Away). As a general rule, I spent a fair amount of the first half of the movie wondering things like, "When are they getting on the boat?", "Why are they not on the boat yet?", "Why do Indians wiggle their heads like that when they talk? Do they think it conveys any message to the listener other than induced confusion?", and, "Wait, does this movie even have a boat in it?"Why you should see it:Perhaps above I didn't mention a fairly big (literally and figuratively) additional character in the movie, specifically in the lifeboat: an adult male Bengal tiger. The tiger has a name, but I won't spoil that for you, and I will just refer to it here as "tiger." So anyway, what you thought was going to be a nice, laid back, somewhat boring adventure on a lifeboat turns out to be, in fact, a second-by-second struggle for survival against a freaking Bengal tiger. In case you're not as familiar as I am with Bengal tigers, just know that they average 500 pounds and are considered to be the most aggressive subspecies of an animal that is known to occasionally eat people.Tiger has a funny name in the movie, and I will give credit to the author and screenwriter for occasionally adding in appropriate moments of humor and everyday humanity into an extraordinary coming of age story. If it hadn't been for the occasional giggle moments in the first half of the movie, I'm not sure I would have made it to the second half. Well, that's an exaggeration, since I'm pretty thoroughly stubborn when it comes to finishing movies, and even more so when it comes to best picture nominees. Still, suffice it to say that there wasn't much to hold my attention for the first hour.All that being said, there is really one main reason that anyone would want to see Life of Pi, and that reason has everything to do with an appreciation for visual art. Once the film reaches the boat, nearly every frame of the movie one could take, frame, and put it up on his or her wall. The visuals are stimulating not only due to the fact that they include crystal clear detail and vivid, saturated colors, but they also depict images that are not frequently seen. You may not be aware, but an adult male Bengal tiger does not often chill out on a lifeboat playing with flying fish in the middle of the ocean. Even in little moments, Lee finds ways to create visual art out of his material. When the opening credits are rolling over footage of a small Indian zoo, the words on the screen behave like the animals on the screen. Sometimes it's the little things.In Short:Life of Pi is visually breathtaking at moments and beautiful for the rest of it. If you have interest in seeing it and aren't opposed to the whole 3D phenomenon, I recommend it as a readily available way to suck you even further into the visuals Lee has created. The story drags at parts for me, and but for the payoff at the end (which I won't spoil for you), I would be happy to write the whole thing off as eye candy and nothing more. But that payoff is there, and as a consequence I've been thinking about it since I saw it almost a week ago. If it weren't for the occasional slowness of the movie itself, I would rate it higher, but for now I'll settle at a 7 out of 10 and recommend it to anyone who likes pretty things and/or exploring the nature of storytelling.Exceptions to the recommendation:- anyone who would prefer to believe that there is no beauty in the world;- people who are frightened by adult male Bengal tigers (just kidding, because that should really be anyone/everyone, and I'm not going to recommend that no one see this movie just because of a healthy respect for one's own mortality when near that particular ornery feline);- militant atheists... I guess I should have mentioned somewhere that this story is set up as proof that God exists and has a fair amount to do with religion... oops;- racists (who aren't Indian);- homophobes who want to stick it to Ang Lee (figuratively) for daring to make a movie about gays (this movie doesn't have any gays to my knowledge, but I figure sticking it to Lee for Brokeback Mountain by not watching Life of Pi makes about as much sense as homophobia in general);- people who don't like irrational numbers.
summary: Worthwhile Theme Wrapped Up In Gorgeous Visuals

reviewText: Before I started watching this movie, I was thinking how in the world could anyone make a movie with a boy and a tiger in the middle of the ocean worth watching. I couldn't even think of one thing that would make it remotely interesting, but this movie surprised me. The beginning won me over with its witty moments. For instance, Pi discovered Islam and then practiced it. Then, I imagine it wasn't a day later he was asking to be baptized in the traditional Christian manner. Pi's mother could only smile. His father thought it was foolish. The story continues and eventually, he discovers Richard, the Bengal tiger, and he is taught a lesson about what the animal really is. I don't think he learned anything from that lesson, and I don't think he ever does. The story kept moving and eventually went to the ship sinking and how Pi came to survive with the tiger.I will admit I was surprised and at awe at this movie. It was thoughtfully written and beautifully presented. I was most interested in the floating carnivorous island, and all the meerkats. That part was so cool, and I was just smiling while watching that part of it. Everyone involved in the creation of this movie did a great job. The hard work and creativity involved did not escape me, and I am glad I took the time to watch it. It was truly refreshing, new, and breathtaking.If this movie won awards for any of the people that worked on it, they surely deserved it. I highly recommend this movie.

reviewText: This is one of the most difficult movies I've had to review in a long time.Why?Because almost everything I've read has been positive and yet every review has had a much different take on the overall meaning of the film.I was expecting a spiritual rebirth for myself somewhat.Unrealistic yes, but that is the kind of praise that's been heaped on this film.I was expecting a movie that was life changing.Well...it wasn't.I didn't get either of those things and yet I don't feel cheated either.And that is the real magic of this film...that everyone will take away something different.Me?I took away a real sense of sorrow and yet I took away an almost calm feeling. I type this with a somewhat mischievous grin on my face because that is another strange feeling that this film gave me.This isn't just a film about a boy lost at sea.It's a film about feelings and how we react to certain situations.It is a film I will revisit many times over the yearsIt is...a difficult but successful movie that will make you ponder the meaning of many things.Brilliant direction.Score, FX, 3D...pretty much everything is absolute perfection.Watch it just once with an open mind.Some will love it, some will hate it, some will never understand it and most of us will take away something different from it than anyone else.And that is the real magic of this film.Very difficult but very rewarding.Recommended.

reviewText: I know some people consider pop-outs gimmicky, preferring unobtrusive 3D. They talk about how enhanced depth is all they want. Well, 2D already has depth, otherwise it would be unwatchable. As far as I'm concerned if things aren't popping out of the screen then 3D is absolutely pointless. The pop-out is, after all, the 3rd dimension.There was virtually no 3D in this film as far as I could tell. Just look at the cover image. How great would it have been to have that giant whale pop out of the screen and into your living room? How about water rushing toward you? Or your living room seemingly engulfed in waves with mist all around? That's what I was expecting when I purchased this film. But none of that was to be found. It's a 2D film packaged as 3D in my opinion. What's the point of wearing clunky and uncomfortable active shutter glasses and putting up with an inferior image if you're not going to get the pop-out payoff?My 2 star rating wasn't just for the lack of any discernible 3D. Let me put it this way, I probably will never watch this movie again. I just wasn't transported by it. 2 hours spent on the ocean with one character and a tiger were a bit much.

reviewText: Life stories aren't always happy.  Pi's life is no exception.  It will fill you full of awe at times, but it will show you lows of great trajedy as well.  It is indeed an adventure, mostly of a young boy and young man. As a young boy his life was tormented by his full name, but filled with joy of learning about religion and animals in his families Zoo.  In time his family must sell out and board a freighter with some of their animals.  Trajedy strikes deep on that voyage, but Pi and a tiger survive.  Their adventure on the high seas is indeed full of wonder, but measured with the struggle of finding water and food.  Pi ends up telling us two stories and letting us decide which we like best.  I like the one with the tiger and I think you will too.  Great directing, acting, production values, and absolutely gorgeous camera work.CA Luster

reviewText: Visually stunning with heartfelt lows and highs the audience can revel in along with the characters.  It is a rare film that you can call "art" but this one qualifies.  The story is amazingly engaging, so much so that I couldn't believe the end was upon me so soon by the conclusion.  This is a testament to the original author but also the adaptation.  As I mentioned the directing and visuals were pure eye candy, yet so tastefully and expertly done that they serve to pull you into the story rather than distract you from it.  Toss in some deep revelations that will leave you in self reflection long after the credits role and you have a modern day masterpiece that is very hard to come by these ADD days and harder to just walk away from when the screen finally goes black.This movie is pretty unique but just to compare the "feel" of it to some others you may have seen to give a general idea of whether it will fit your viewing mood at the moment: take 3 parts Cast Away, mix with 1 part Big Fish, add a dash of We Bought a Zoo and just a pinch of Hugo and mix thoroughly on the high seas.
summary: Hard To Come By and Harder to Leave

reviewText: Pi is a precocious Indian boy from Pondicherry, India.  His family owns a zoo.  In that zoo is a Bengal Tiger named Richard Parker.  Pi is also a spiritual child, rebelling against his rationalist "New India" father.  In his spiritual journey, Pi melds Christianity, Islam and Hinduism in his effort to find and love God.  A cynic might interpret this as a touchy-feely globalist literary prop to make the movie more likeable to a broad global audience whose members are actually locked in post-enlightenment zeitgeist of religious war and tension.  That same cynic might also add that the true god of Corporate Globalism is a one-out-of-three unholy trinity of Migrants, Mammon, & Moloch.The political situation shifts in India and Pi and his family sell the zoo and transport the animals on a Japanese freighter for Canada.  On the ship they meet a rude French cook, a kind-hearted Japanese sailor and look after their animals.  One night there is a terrible storm and the freighter sinks, Pi is the only human survivor.  On the lifeboat, which is half covered by canvas, is an injured zebra, an female orangutan who has lost her baby to the sea, and a vicious hyena.  As the shipwrecked zoo progress on their journey, the hyena kills the zebra, than the orangutan, and then suddenly , Richard Parker, the Bengal Tiger leaps from under the canvas, killing the hyena.  Pi is then alone, with a vicious tiger.  Pi must tame the great cat and use his wits to help them both survive.In an epic of surreal filmography Pi and Richard Parker drift across the Pacific, during one storm Pi sees Almighty Providence, when he tries to show the sight to Richard Parker, the tiger is seized with fear and must duck under the canvas.  In a delirium, Pi and Richard Parker wash up on a strange island-a garden of plenty by day but death by night.  Eventually, Pi washes up on a beach in tropical Mexico, and the tiger returns to the to jungle without looking back. Pi is then rescued by natives.At this point, the viewer is left with an unsettled feeling.  Pi's more important journey with God is soul-less, globalist nonsense, his reconciliation is nowhere near as believable as Lieutenant Dan's Jacob-like wrestling with God while tied to the mast of a shrimp boat during Hurricane Camille.However cynicism drops away and the entire meaning of the movie changes in retrospect with a subtle plot twist. Pi speaks to some Japanese officials in a Mexican hospital.  They are investigating the shipwreck as part of an insurance claim.  They don't believe his story.  He tells a different story-one of a dying, kind-hearted sailor, a resourceful and Darwinian French cook, and his scared mother in a lifeboat.  This story is darker, more emotionally taxing, and involves murder and cannibalism.  Without letting on which story is true, Pi mentions that the tiger Richard Parker was much like his Id, his will to survive, his inner-evil.  During the storm, when Pi sees The Almighty, Richard Parker can only tremble in terror.  This, second story takes the movie to a higher level.  It is a story that sticks in the mind, causing one to think backwards about the nuanced, subtle details in the story.  A viewer then picks at the suddenly real, suddenly rich, and suddenly colorful spiritual symbolism.I wish I could give it six stars.
summary: The Life of Pi is an incredible story of man vs. nature with a mind-bending plot twist at the end

reviewText: A 2001 novel of the same name by Yann Martel is the basis for "Life of Pi" and it has been called unfilmable. The movie has been in the works since 2003, but the nature of the film has caused many to think that it would never be possible. See, most of the film involves a boy in a lifeboat with an adult Bengal Tiger. The movie also involves many other challenging things to portray, including a massive shipwreck, an island of meerkats and a strong religious overtone that manages to be fair to all religions. Suraj Sharma plays Pi Patel, a boy becoming a man who challenges all conventional thinking as he leads his life. Curious about religion and religions, he prides himself in knowing not just one god, but all gods. Not to mention, despite its obvious carnivorous nature, he has faith that a Bengal Tiger named Richard Parker has a soul and can be befriended."Life of Pi" has many levels and as visually stimulating as it is, it is also mentally stimulating and beautiful in its intent. I'm not completely sure it achieved all that it intended but the gist of its message comes across loud and clear. Life is a gift and the days ahead are not guaranteed. Faith is vital in living a rewarding life and in knowing how life is not only to be lived, but to be cherished for each and every moment. I'm pretty sure that was the gist.Above all, "Life of Pi" is not just a well-filmed movie, but a gloriously well filmed film. The quality levels of the filming are unprecedented and its 3D makes all 3D that has been done prior look like the second and third-rate stuff that it is. The effects used to bring the tiger Richard Parker to life are awe-inspiring. Your eyes widen, as they should, when Parker strikes and when he nears. There has certainly never before been a movie that gives you the impression of what it would be like to be and live in the proximity of such a beast."Life of Pi" comes off a little heavy-handed at time and I have to admit that I assumed there would be more to it, but the amount there is to it is in the eye of the beholder. You can look at the movie and say that it wasn't about much, or you can look at the movie and say that it was about everything, because it is. The performances are outstanding, including the Tiger, and the film is without question, one of the best of 2012.
summary: BEAUTIFULLY FILMED a little heavy handed

reviewText: The movie version of Life of Pi is directed by Ang Lee and includes quite a lot of computer graphics. It looks good in 3D and is well acted. Suraj Sharma and Irrfan Khan deserve a special mention as the young and adult Pi. Gerard Depardieu plays a small but significant role. Adil Hussain and Tabu are excellent as Pi's parents. The screenplay is fairly true to the book, but there is a romance element that has obviously been added, Hollywood style, and is completely unnecessary. There is a scene in the ship's dining room which, while not in the book, obviously serves as a device to give background for the alternative story by introducing the sailor who breaks his leg, and the cook. I was sorry the scene with the priest, the imam and the pandit was omitted. While the CGI and 3D effects were brilliant, I felt the storm/sinking ship scenes asked the viewer to suspend disbelief a little too much: how did Pi manage to get back to the lifeboat from so far away in the high seas? I was glad I had recently reread the book so I was completely familiar with it, and I feel the movie kept the overall spirit and feel of the book. Would I watch it again? Definitely! Would I recommend seeing it in 3D? Absolutely!

reviewText: Ang Lee's "Life of Pi" is a masterpiece of state-of-the-art film making, a beautiful creation that tells a moving story in heart-touching way.Starting from the very opening credits, it is a gorgeous film to watch.  Filmed in vibrant color and mostly natural settings, with animals featured in many scenes, it is more visually stunning than any nature documentary I've ever seen.  The scenes at sea, both at night under the stars and during the day, under a wide variety of different ocean conditions, show the true beauty and terrifying power of the open ocean.  Certainly some of the scenes, especially the phosphoresence scenes, are computer enhanced, but the net effect is spectacular.The animals, especially the Bengal tiger, are the costars of the movie, and their actions are incredibly lifelike and true to their animal nature.  This is no Disney film - in only one short scene does the tiger exhibit any humanlike traits.  I have no idea how Ang Lee actually created and captured these animal scenes on film - the special effects are so good, with no hints of fakery, that you will believe that all the scenes really were filmed at sea with the lead actor on a small boat alongside a hungry, vicious tiger.  This is present-day special effects at its absolute best, and in service to a movie that is not a science fiction shoot-em-up.  Impressive.The movie's story is about stories: how they are created and retold, and the impact they have on people.  "Life of Pi" has some interesting things to say about religion, because the documents at the heart of all major religions are effectively books of stories, very little of which can actually be proven or verified to have happened.  Pi's story about what happened at sea on his boat where he was the only human survivor is no different, and when you can't scientifically verify something, the question becomes what do you believe?  "Life of Pi" leaves it to the viewer to decide."Life of Pi" is quite an achievement for director Ang Lee.  I think I know why Hollywood voted the "Hollywood saves the day" film Argo as the Oscar's Best Picture of 2012, but "Life of Pi" is a far better and much more memorable movie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ang Lee is a director that most individuals don't seem to be too fond of. To this day, his "Hulk" film remains unwatched because so many people have offered their opinion that it's awful. "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" is in the same category, but for different reasons. Wuxia films are almost always better when the wire work is more subtle and "Crouching Tiger" looks to take no shame in everyone flying around at all times. "Brokeback Mountain" was the only Lee film to be experienced before "Life of Pi" and that was solely because seeking out Heath Ledger's work seemed like a pretty vital thing to do after "The Dark Knight." Going into "Life of Pi," there was literally no interest. The book hadn't been read beforehand and trailers had not been seen. Expectations were mostly, "It may be gorgeous to look at, but will lack any sort of depth." One of the best feelings in the world is having your misconceptions about something be completely wrong and work out in ways you never imagined."Life of Pi" is narrated by an older Pi (Irrfan Khan) and takes place in the present as he tells his life story to a writer (Rafe Spall). Pi begins with how he got his name and how his family owned a zoo, but eventually leads into his family needing to leave India for financial purposes. The heart of the story lies in Pi as a young man (played by Suraj Sharma) and the time he spent out at sea on a lifeboat with a tiger named Richard Parker, but getting to that point is quite an ordeal. Pi loses everything and everyone close to him in the blink of an eye and he doesn't count on making what feels like an unbreakable bond with a Bengal tiger.The story is first introduced to the writer by a friend of the family called Mamaji and tells the writer that Pi's story will "make him believe in God." Mamaji is a champion swimmer and there's at least one really spectacular sequence at the beginning of the film where you see Mamaji swimming. The film is shot beautifully and makes full use of eye catching perspectives including overhead shots of the ocean. Pi begins on the lifeboat with a zebra, a hyena, and an orangutan, but the animals are an intricate part of the story. It's not entirely seamless as you can tell when real animals are being used and when CG enters the picture, but the transition from one to the other is relatively flawless.The adventure film offers a rather marvelous message about religion as Pi discusses the experimentation with several different religions as a young boy. Even though it seems kind of silly that a boy has adopted so many religions at one point in his life, it portrays a religious message in a light that doesn't seem too preachy which is very welcome and unusual for a message of this caliber. But the religious aspect is really only a backdrop for being on your own path to finding who you really are. Feeling so alone for so long and having Pi talk about not being alone and not getting to say goodbye to those he cared about most is one of those things that just hits you really hard.While witnessing Pi attempt to tame Richard Parker is really entertaining, there are so many unbelievable sights to witness in "Life of Pi." There's the whale, the jellyfish, the flying fish, that disastrous storm, and that seaweed island with all of the meerkats. "Life of Pi" never really lets up on being visually astounding from beginning to end. A personal favorite is when Pi starts seeing visions in the ocean and what he questions as being a daydream or a night dream."Life of Pi" is pleasantly satisfying. With a heartfelt message, beautiful visuals, and stunning camera work, "Life of Pi" is truly a sight to behold and illustrates how essential 3D can be to a film that isn't a summer blockbuster.
summary: A dazzling voyage of self discovery

reviewText: Yann Martel's novel, Life of Pi, had long been considered unfilmable until Oscar-winning director, Ang Lee (Brokeback Mountain), did the impossible.  He (with an adaptation by screenwriter David Magee) has made a visually stunning adventure about ultimate survival and the meaning of existence in the universe.  It is a unique film experience and one that requires openness and a certain suspension of disbelief.Pi is an impressionable young boy whose exposure to religion develops into an embracing of more than one faith much to the consternation of his father.  The family owns a zoo in the French part of India and one day are forced to uproot their lives and head to Canada by cargo ship.  During a powerful storm, the ship sinks and all hands are lost except Pi, orphaned and stranded in the middle of the Pacific Ocean with no help and a lifeboat filled with an unlikely manifest: wild animals including a tiger, oddly named Richard Parker.  An unusual dynamic plays out as Pi struggles to stay alive in the elements and contend with the ferocious beast.  As the hours turn into days and then weeks, Pi, left with only his instincts and ingenuity, is forced to improvise and utilize all his survival skills amid dwindling supplies.  When hope begins to fade for rescue, some unlikely, awe inspiring events occur that mean the difference between life and death.Lee, no stranger to computer generated effects (Hulk, Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon), has done a major accomplishment here by adapting the challenging logistics of the source material and making it accessible and compelling to an audience.  He is no doubt aided by incredible advancements in special visual effects that form a significant portion of the film and recreate unforgettable moments including the fatal storm and the sinking cargo ship, the wondrous, luminescent phenomenon at night, and the depiction of animals in the lifeboat especially the tiger, Richard Parker, who becomes a major character.  Some of the imagery is remarkable in 3-D.Suraj Sharma is quite convincing as the young Pi; it's a one man show for a majority of the film. The story, told in a flashback, is about Pi's ascension to manhood, and he is in essence is a citizen of the world, not having been bound to any one religion.  His curiosity and spiritual journey serve to make this an allegorical tale, and it is his relationship with Richard Parker that serves as a foundation to the story.  He wonders about his deadly companion and ponders the question, "Do animals have souls?"  In essence, Parker is Pi's Wilson (from Castaway) but with a soul.  Pi's interaction with the ocean is not unlike the solitary figures in The Old Man and the Sea and 127 Hours, in which mother nature can be lovely and deadly, giving and taking, a sort of protagonist and antagonist.There are unanswered questions.  What really becomes of Richard Parker? And are we to believe this fantastic tale as fact or fiction or a warped truth?  Is there a more plausible explanation?  Maybe that's just the point of the story: that life is full of questions and wonder, and sometimes truth is stranger than fiction no matter how unlikely it may appear.  Audiences who are willing to completely open their hearts and minds, will find a rewarding experience in this tragic yet fascinating exploration into the miracle of life.  And the movie does look hauntingly beautiful.
summary: The Meaning of Existence in LIFE OF PI

reviewText: I really liked the book.  That said I accept that a movie can never have as much information in it as a book (unless it is a very short book), and that movies are visual representations of what goes on around a character, and most books tend to look inside the character - thus the translation from books to film has an inherent flaw that will always be there.  That didn't stop me from wanting to see this film, because, c'mon: you just want to SEE the boy on the lifeboat with the tiger from the moment you start to read that section of the book.  In that this movie succeeded very well.  Special effects are getting better and better, and where-as in Jumanji, the CGI animals pulled you out of the movie - these succeed in being believable.  All in all a pretty faithful adaptation, with some very beautiful visuals.
summary: Pretty fair adaptation of the book

reviewText: I was assigned to read Yann Martel's LIFE OF PI in a college freshman lit class over Thanksgiving break.  I had the misfortune to fall sick that Monday, and was bedridden until Friday.  Martel's novel kept me company; in between bouts of passing out, I'd read about the epic journey of young Pi--a journey both physical and spiritual.  I loved the novel; after six years of college literary courses, it remains the only book I've been assigned that I subsequently went out and purchased, and reread, before the course was over.I never expected, or wanted, to see a film version.  Like many great books, PI is rooted in its literary origins.  And as such, the film version does suffer slightly--what comes off as exciting and insightful in the novel can seem somewhat boring and lackluster (at least, plot-wise) onscreen.  This is only to be expected.  And yet, David Magee's script sticks faithfully with the novel, right down to much of the dialogue.  In the form of our tortured hero--I use the word lightly; "protagonist" would be a better term--we have Suraj Sharma, giving a solid performance (the fantastic Irrfan Khan plays the older Pi, with Rafe Spall playing the Writer).  The problem with the film, aside from the slow pace (which isn't nearly so slow in book form) is that Sharma is out-acted by everything around him; that's only to be expected when you have a film that looks so absolutely beautiful.  WIth vibrant colors, rich textures, and just an overal REALNESS to the cinematography, PI blew me away (and I only watched the 2D version).But the true star here is Richard Parker, Pi's carnivorous raft-mate.  Perhaps the pinnacle of modern CGI (an actual tiger was used for some shots, but mostly it's the computers), Richard Parker comes truly to life under Ang Lee and company's masterful hands.  The fact that a fake tiger is the focal point of LIFE OF PI isn't an accident; it's a beautiful film with a dangerous edge, easily mistaken as a life-affirming, optimistic piece.  Truthfully, the film follows the novel's spirit as well as plot: you take from it what you bring to it.  Maybe its ambiguity in such matters can be counted against it; if the movie (and novel) had taken a true stand, there might be more to admire.  Still, LIFE OF PI--whichever form you approach it in, though I highly recommend the novel, even if Martel's other works fall short--is a story to make you think.  Maybe you'll walk away happy, maybe you'll walk away depressed, maybe you'll just be frustrated and confused; the point is, you'll walk away feeling SOMETHING.  And if that's not the point of art, then I'm not sure what is.

reviewText: First, I just have to say a technical word. Most of the good reviews of this film rave about the "3D" version, and frankly this makes me a little sick. Beautifully photographed, yes, but you don't need to see it in 3D, a passing fancy, to be impressed by the incedible visual impact of this film. It is a Lee masterpiece, and you can hear Louis Armstrong on an old 33/rd pressing of the song "It's a wonderful world", and be just as impressed, in fact more so, than hearing it on a modern CD. So let's let the technocrats go here! Those glasses stink.Second, this is clearly a "fable", in its most wonderous sort. The second story Pi tells to the Japanese insurance agents is the True Story, while the movie shows us the Fable. Now, the fable is not a figment of imagination for Pi, it is his only way of saving himself from insanity on an "Ocean of Loneliness" and desperation. He believes it to be true. This is the same way that Ennis in the wonderful "Brokeback Mountain", also protects himself in his own ocean storm, convincing himself that he visits Jack's room, in Jack's family home with the strange settings and the equally strange parents, and retrieves some of Jack's clothing. The visit is a dream, and it gives poor Ennis just a bit of closure with the loss of his only love. The same with Pi. Having lost everything, his closure is yes, indeed, to "become the Tiger". When he is finally beached and rescued, the Tiger leaving him, without a goodbye, is an essential part of his soul departing, and the complete realization of this change and his tragic loss, breaks Pi's heart.You see, Lee, is a master of the psyche and the heart. He knows how to adapt a novel or screenplay to wring every bit of the "real" reality of the story, and how through the most compelling of needs, the imagination of humanity must create its fables to save its "reality", to create "alternate realities", completely believeable, and to the "mind", the truest creation of them all. This goes to the utter sadness of this movie, since all Pi has loved had died,and only Pi, the great Tiger of the mind, the admirer of so many religions in his youth, must live on. As his Father suggests early on "get reason, first". Pi, on the otherhand, survives, while "reason" finds a horrible and unending death. Fables lead to myths, and then to legends, and these finally are what casts us adrift to ceasely keep navigating our "boats against the stream". "Reason", as the Bard said so aptly, "doth make cowards of us all". I prefer the first version.

reviewText: I'm one of the few people that couldn't get into the book this movie is adapted from. Try as I might, I thought it moved extremely slow and it had a hard time holding my attention. With this in mind, I went into the theater for the film expecting to feel the same way when it was over. Suffice to say, at the end of the movie I felt emotionally rewarded and thoroughly entertained.In fact, it was one of the most visually pleasing films I've seen in a while and I was very impressed with the cast. A lot of credit has to be given to newcomer Suraj Sharma as the title character, who brings a lot of passion and emotion to the screen. His performance was top notch and I look forward to seeing him in future roles. I was also impressed with Irfan Khan who plays the adult version of Pi, whose role in the film is the retelling of his story to a novelist. Equally impressive was Ang Lee's direction of the film. Many critics described "Life of Pi" as the "unfilmable" book but Lee does a magnificent job with the task and doesn't waste any opportunities to wow the audience with breathtaking visuals.This movie more than exceeded my expectations. If you enjoyed the book, you're sure to enjoy the movie. If you're like me and you just couldn't enjoy the book, give the movie a shot. This may be one of those rare occasions in which the movie is better than the book it's adapter from. Highly recommended.
summary: A Breathtaking & Majestic Adaptation of an "Unfilmable" Book

reviewText: Too many films depend on special effects alone to drive their film.  It's that rare bird, Martin Scorsese's "Hugo" comes to mind, where the effects are there to enhance the story.  "Life of Pi" joins that select company.  What director Ang Lee has devised here is nothing short of a miracle.  You will find yourself transfixed by this tale of young Pi Patel (Suraj Sharma) cast adrift in the ocean after the freighter carrying he, his family, and a menagerie of zoo animals capsizes. This film is a testament to will, determination, and faith that keeps Pi alive to survive his ordeal.  Much has been said about Ang Lee's direction and there's no diminishing that but I felt that Sharma to be the driving force of the film.  This is a case of a director and an actor working in communion to make something of lasting impact.  There are no adjectives that can sufficiently describe what a wonder this film is.

reviewText: First of all I want to explain the five stars; this is not casual entertainment suitable for a pleasant evening with a relaxing movie, it is intense and provocative drama that will shake you until your teeth rattle. It does an outstanding job of providing a surprisingly serious plunge into drama, excitement, and visual beauty that is not easily forgotten.We watched this last night for the first time without having read the book or any reviews so this review is strictly on the movie itself. This is a powerful and effective movie which grabs you by the shoulders and gives you a good long shake. It doesn't let go even after the movie is over as one's mind speculates on the alternative stories and considers which one to be really true.Visually the movie is graphic and powerful and has a variety of strong images mixed with beauty and wonder; if you watch it late at night you may have trouble sleeping. I've found it hard to put the images and thoughts of the movie behind me as scenes from the movie keep returning to my mind.I recommend you approach this movie with caution as it is a force with which to be reckoned and can imbed itself in your memories.

reviewText: The Life of PI is really about dealing with grief.  It was slow moving at first building a required foundation, once the action started you cannot turn from the screen.  It has a twist at the end that might be a surprise.  It leaves you to ponder, what survival skills do you have, how do you deal with loss and trauma, is rigid religion preferable with death or can you find ways to manage during the crisis. Above all, we discover that no matter what happens, life goes on and each of us finds strength from deep within and from our roots.

reviewText: of course the ordering of the stories is different...story 1 ends the film. and story 2, as i say, IS the film (almost), accompanied with some "real world" context (introduction and final exit of protagonist)...pi begins intelligently, and from that point it extends to always increasing levels of beauty... for minds prepared to appreciate it...for those that are not, as it is also very philosophical, it seems to me that it will require a patience that cannot be sustained... as with all intricate pieces...whether you watch or not is not a test, only whether it leaves you better off than it found you...your call...ciao.
summary: story 1 is brief, engaging, and tragic...story 2 is nearly the entire film, and a visually seductive morality piece

reviewText: For me, this movie was realistic enough not to brush off, and fantastic enough to set my imagination aflame. The visual effects were positively Avatar-like, although I have seen neither in 3-D, only Blu-ray. Even with that limitation on my part, "Life of Pi" was a cinematic work of art. Also, the story is a great one. As with "Slumdog Millionaire," it focuses on a young Indian man in a seemingly impossible situation. Suffice to say, adversity grows the soul. But that is where any similarity with "Slumdog Millionaire" ends. My best advice is to give this movie a chance and experience its best qualities. It may not change your life, but it can brighten your day. Enjoy! Fr. Dennis

reviewText: I only bought this thing because the ad was calling it the next Avatar.  Uh, not even close. Putting that masterpiece's title and the name of this...movie in the same sentence together is criminal.Trying to think what I like about this movie.  The glow in the dark water and the cool whale breaching.  I love tigers and it hurt my eyes watching even an animated tiger slowly starve (or nearly starve to death).  The zebra would have been screaming in agony and should have been destroyed.  At once.  Instead of being put through even more trauma by the rocking pitching motion of the boat.Oh, but that would be realism...showing the resulting pain that would come from a broken leg.Criminy. Sorry.  I could be on a deserted island with nothing but a DVD player and this movie lying there, and I'd still rather play tick tack toe in the sand than watch this film a second time.

reviewText: A great marriage of drama and CGI makes this a compelling movie of the year. reviewText: Having yet to read the book, I watched the film mainly as an illuminator for the novel, which I am now eager to start. I can only say that LIFE of PI is like no other film that I have ever seen. I expected it to be good but also feared it might have some of those fluffy "Oh, aren't I deep and brilliant?!" qualities. My fears proved baseless. LIFE of PI incorporates mystical and philosophical themes very well without detracting from its engaging, hypnotic storyline. It's also touching and poignant without being the least bit sentimental. Despite a few choppy bits, there isn't a seriously dull moment here. Suraj Sharma/Irrfan Khan play the protagonist quite convincingly, but it's the fine cinematography that really makes this film. Absolutely stunning views of the ocean and its life and, of course, Richard Parker the tiger and various other animals.
summary: "The whole of life is letting go"

reviewText: LIFE OF PI is quite simply a visual feast of spectacle.  From the Indian locations of Pondicherry in the past, to the sequences taking place at sea, a quite wonderful evocation of an uninhabited island where the plants are predatory, to the final sequence taking place in sunlit suburbia in Canada, the film is full of memorable images.  The moments involving the animals - especially Richard Parker the tiger - are equally memorable; if they have been created using CGI, they certainly did not seem so.  Director Ang Lee has a wonderful way of suggesting the animal's predatory nature, yet at the same time its straightforwardness (unlike the human characters).  At the same time, I have to admit that the plot of LIFE OF PI is slight, to say the least: one can understand the central character's desire to discover himself and his relationship to God, but the progress of moving towards self-awareness is sometimes a slow one.  The film drags on occasions; one wishes that more character-conflict had been introduced, especially involving Gérard Depardieu, who has a memorable cameo as an obstreperous ship's cook.
summary: A Visual Feast, but not Much Else
Title: N/A

reviewText: Castaway meets Planet Earth with a few pointed spiritual overtones thrown in for good measure. As the plot slowly develops, it takes the slant of a classical fantasy adventure, akin to the serial novels and comic strips of the early 20th century, granting the screen an entrancing, otherworldly sensibility. As is, that would've been a perfectly acceptable stylistic decision - after all, director Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon made no apologies for its less-grounded moments - but such stylish exaggerations actually become an essential part of the telling when an admission in the final act changes everything we'd just seen. Magnificently composed and spectacularly beautiful, it would be worth watching for the eye candy alone. Lee's restraint in this regard is especially impressive; he knows precisely when his audience will want to linger in a moment and indulges them with one breath-catching vista after another. Kudos to the enormous team of effects artists; their combined efforts have produced a cinematic masterpiece. A bit sluggish at times, with a few moments that tease the boundaries of plausibility, its visuals are a revelation and I'm still considering some of the story's underlying meanings a day later. Worth experiencing.
summary: More Than Just the Story of a Boy and His Tiger

reviewText: Everybody has their own version of the truth, and the way we frame our own stories may have a great deal to do with a higher level of consciousness for which we all strive. Such is the gist of Yann Martel's 2001 bestseller which is the basis of this visually stunning 2012 adventure drama helmed by Ang Lee (Brokeback Mountain). I read the book several years ago and remember thinking it would make a great animated film by someone as creative as Hayao Miyazaki (Howl's Moving Castle). CGI, however, has evolved so dramatically in the past decade that the story can be now inhabited by real actors and awash in gorgeous abstraction that melds the fantastical with the intimate quite seamlessly. Shot mostly in a giant tank in Taiwan as well as on location in India, this movie is a unique example of how technology's endless possibilities can well serve an allegorical story focused on human survival and our own individual coping mechanisms.Adapted by David Magee (Finding Neverland), the story is framed by an interview in Montreal between a Canadian writer, a fictionalized version of Martel, and an unassuming middle-aged man named Pi. The first part of the film is a flashback set in a family-run zoo in Pondicherry, a bucolic former French colony in southern India. The central protagonist is Pi as a child whose sternly sensible father runs the zoo. We learn the origins of Pi's unusual name as it relates to an impossibly pristine pool in which his uncle swam in Paris. At once, you get a sense of the importance of both water and mathematics in Pi's early life as well as his unfiltered concept of religion. In Pi's fertile mind, which religion is a moot point as he adopts Hinduism, Christianity and Islam concurrently and despite his family's resistance. A life-endangering confrontation with a Bengal tiger under their care proves to be a turning point for Pi as he is warned by his supportive family to stay away from it. Later economic hardship prompts his father to decide to move to Canada where he plans to sell the animals.The stormy journey by freighter turns tragic around the Mariana Trench where the now-teenaged Pi finds himself on a lifeboat with an unlikely menagerie in tow. The party eventually dwindles down to two, and this is where Lee imbues the film with a surreal spirit befitting the tale as we watch the seemingly incredulous situation of Pi co-existing on the lifeboat with the same tiger we saw in his childhood encounter. Dubbed Richard Parker due to a previous mix-up in paperwork, the tiger is integral to a series of eye-catching episodes that involves flying fish pelting them with force, a plethora of glowing jellyfish at night, a breaching whale nearly capsizing the boat, a disastrous storm that carries them to the brink, and a bizarrely florid island overrun with carnivorous plants and curious meerkats. None of these episodes will surprise readers of the book, but the execution is enthralling thanks to the masterful work of Chilean cinematographer Claudio Miranda (The Curious Case Of Benjamin Button) and the visual effects generated by the Rhythm & Hues Studios.Similarities to Robert Zemeckis'Cast Awayand Alfred Hitchcock'sLifeboatare probably not without intention on Lee's part, but this movie manages to hold its own. My one complaint about the film comes toward the end when things are spelled out a bit too deliberately considering how symbolic the story has been expressed up to that point. Pi is played by four actors depicting the character at different ages. Suraj Sharma effectively portrays Pi during the challenging lifeboat sequence and obviously makes the strongest impression, but Gautam Belur and Ayush Tandon are also affecting in conveying Pi's evolving psyche during his tender childhood years. Irrfan Khan (The Namesake) plays Pi in the present with his becalming demeanor seemingly at odds with the incredulous story he tells Martel. Khan's movie wife from "The Namesake", Tabu, shows up as Pi's understanding mother, and Gérard Depardieu appears inexplicably in a cameo as the freighter ship's nasty cook. Rafe Spall (One Day) plays Martel in a rather nondescript manner. It's not a perfect film, but many of the sumptuous images will likely stick with you for a long while afterward.
summary: Sumptuous, CGI-Generated Images Bring Martel's Book Vividly to Life
