reviewText: I'll review this for your benefit, not mine. That is, I may value certain aspects of a movie more or less than you do, or vice versa. For example, someone who flees the room if there's any violence in a movie won't want to see this firm, despite its PG rating. There's violence and it's a scary movie at times. Not like, say, "Saving Private Ryan" but it isn't an episode of "Friends" either.And after seeing this film last night (and never having read the book or read about the book), I would make a few blanket recommendations:1. See this in 3D unless 3D makes you oopsy (as it does a friend of my wife's). I think most people would agree that this film goes far past poke-you-in-the 3D, but instead makes the visual depth integral with the cinematography.2. See this in Blu-Ray if not in a theater. Its visual quality is both right up there at the state of the art, AND it's a major part of the film's appeal.3. Avoid reading any other reviews of the film but this one before you see it, because I won't give you any spoilers, and most reviewers--pro and amateur--do. And in the case of "Life of Pi" it's really important to avoid spoilers. This movie is especially skillful at giving nothing away as you go along, while not "cheating" and hiding anything either. A friend who had seen it before warned me to suspect my sense of disbelief for this--that I wouldn't be sorry afterwards, despite my tendency to dissect-as-I-go, and she was right.Why you might not want to see this film:1. It's not a typical "good" Hollywood film, with a propulsive plot and an array of famous stars you enjoy watching in films. None of the actors are much known in America. So despite some intense action sequences, on the whole it's not a swiftly-paced film.2. It's not a love story. And if you enjoy watching beautiful men and women interact onscreen for a couple of hours, this ain't that. It's a half-naked 17 year old boy not interacting with other people through most of it (though not uninterruptedly).3. It's not an action movie per se.4. It's not a horror movie, and it's not really any other well-known genre. I was reminded a bit of Terence Malick's films like "The Thin Red Line," which is more a meditation on war than a regular war movie.5. This is a bit of a judgment call, but I'd say the screenwriting and acting are competent but not spectacular. However, the visuals throughout are spectacular. The plot is interesting, though some say it isn't as philosophically deep as it thinks it is. Could be; not a big problem for me.6. If you're a religious ideologue, firmly committed to your faith--whatever it is--and believing all other faiths are worthless and must be shunned, you're going to find this off-putting. Maybe you could watch it with the sound off for the glorious visuals.7. I would have taken my kids to see this film when they were young, but only after talking about it with them to make sure they wanted to see a film that skirts the upper end of violence and scary action acceptable in a PG film. Parents who are raising their kid in a "sweetness & light" bubble shouldn't take their kids to see it.Why you might want to see it:1. The absolute state of the art in 3D cinematography and mise-en-scene, and in a director exploiting 3D for narrative effect and not just 3D for 3D's sake.2. A tale that's more interesting in retrospect than it was during most of the movie--it definitely left me mulling it over afterwards, and satisfyingly so.3. Absence of the shadow big box office stars cast over a story.4. If you're a scuba diver like me, or just like watching underwater specials, there are some great visuals for us here, and as a diver I can tell you that the underwater stuff is solidly reality-based, fantastic though some of it seems. Probably the same goes for anyone who's a naturalist of some sort. A lot of Wonders of Nature here.5. If you're religious but very ecumenical or nonreligious but not judgmental about religion (except for the fundamentalist stuff), you'll probably enjoy this movie. It definitely has that "we are all One with the Infinite, and it/them/him/her with us" vibe.6. It doesn't anthropomorphize the animals in the film. Unsentimental, really.7. If you're a woman or a homosexual man you might enjoy watching a half-naked 17 year old youth for the better part of two hours. Me being neither this wasn't a drawing card for me but I'm sure it would be for some, and my job here isn't to tell myself whether or not to see it, but to tell you--whoever you are.8. This is one of those films that I think will be talked about for years, so it you're a film buff, you probably need to have seen it just to keep up with movie conversations.9. This would be a great movie to see with the whole family and talk about afterwards, as long as your kids can handle the most violence & scary action possible for a film to have & still get a PG rating.----------------------------------------------------I didn't leave the theater powerfully moved, but then I AM a scuba diver, so I've seen a lot of marine stuff myself, up close and personal. I thoroughly enjoyed it, though--enough to write a review here.One last note: I've been stranded by myself in the open ocean with no rescue in sight several times. It only lasted a matter of minutes, but I can tell you it's an intense experience even when it's short (one time after a night dive on a moonless night in an obscure chain of islands west of New Guinea was especially intense). So I can relate to the castaway aspect of this film--which is its heart in some ways--in ways that are outside the personal experience of most filmgoers. And I think this does a fair job of capturing that feeling. It brought back my memories of floating along in the water pretty strongly!I will have other conversations about "Life of Pi" with friends who have seen it, but I won't spoil it for you by going into those aspects.
summary: No-spoilers review--and you really want that for this one!

reviewText: The author, not yet 40 (amazingly) when he wrote the book, has been quoted as saying:"Suddenly, my mind was exploding with ideas. I could hardly keep up with them. In jubilant minutes whole portions of the novel emerged fully formed: the lifeboat, the animals, the intermingling of the religious and the zoological, the parallel stories.  Where did that moment of inspiration come from? Why did I think that religion and zoology would make a good mix? ...I could give approximate answers. That India, where there are so many animals and religions, lent itself to such a story. That tensions simmering just below my level of consciousness were probably feverishly pushing me to come up with a story. But in truth I don't know. It just happened.""It just happened...." the rendering of raw life into something far more profound, something universal, a tale known by heart by an unfortunate number of souls who have experienced a "shipwreck"; and, a morality tale, one that can transcend the obvious carnal horror and touch upon that which is beyond our experience, that in which our experience has its being, and its purpose.What is a shipwreck? One is journeying toward something, with hope, and the vicissitudes of life foul the journey.  When the "ship" goes down, everything is lost.  One is left in a hostile world surrounded by the unknown and the horizon disappears twice a day, dawn and dusk, into itself.  There are no markers, there are no maps.A tragedy for which there are no words, a loss so deep that it rivals the power of nature, an ocean of loss.  I know this by heart. I, too, now live with a very large and very dangerous animal.  This is a fight for survival, it is no game, it is no fairy tale.  I feed the beast as best I can and try to avoid it.  Ultimately, I must learn about it and it must - in some way - co-exist with me.  Together, uncomfortable companions, we seek safe harbor.  Safe harbor is far from safe, it is self-consuming.  The only safety is in not looking for it; the only path is back into the journey, the beast and I, toward life.  Can we find it, can we survive? I will not be consumed by the beast, but neither can I consume it.  We are together now, whatever the future.Shall I tell my story in its brutal reality, tearing into the consciousness and sensitivities of those who hear it?  I learn that this is not a prudent choice.  And so I tell it in this way, as I have said, the beast and I.  Everyone fears the beast, do they not?  Yet, not everyone travels with one, and so the story can be safely told.There is magic and even beauty in even the worst horror.  Nothing is without purpose; this is part of the lesson.You cannot tame the beast.  There must be a partnership, a reluctant partnership.  You may find comfort in the oddest of places and when least expected but, ultimately, you must continue the journey.  Or die trying."Even when God seemed to have abandoned me, He was watching.  Even when He seemed indifferent to my suffering, He was watching.  And when I was beyond all hope of saving, He gave me rest, and gave me a sign to continue my journey."Evil and horror are real, but they are encapsulated, they are quarantined from the essential element of soul.  The beast can enter our lives; we can succumb to the horror and be eaten alive, by our own lack of hope and loss of faith.  Or we can arrive at a place where we, and our beast, co-exist.  I am not yet at the place where my beast leaves me.  Perhaps I never will be.  There is something in us that wants to hold onto the beast.  And we are left with two stories: the horror or the hope."Can I ask you something?""Of course.""I've told you two stories  about what happened out on the ocean.  Neither explains what caused the sinking of the ship and no one can prove which story is true and which is not.  In both stories, the ship sinks, my family dies, and I survive.""True.""So which story do you prefer?""The one with the tiger, that's the better story.""Thank you.  And so it goes with God."Go in peace.

reviewText: It's not often that I say that a movie is better than the book upon which it was based. But Life of Pi takes what I thought was a simple and unemotive book and creates a visually stunning and emotionally evocative movie.As other reviews are noted, this movie is a visual masterpiece. Ang Lee injects the film with a bold and unique visual style. There's rarely a boring frame in this movie. There's always an interesting composition or lighting effect on the screen. That's no small achievement given that the story primarily takes place on a small boat with a single actor and a CGI tiger. I'm not often wowed by special effects, but some of the shots from underwater really were impressive.I think Ang Lee and actor Suraj Sharma did a great job at drawing the emotional story out of this book. As I wrote in my review of the novel, the writing style is a bit dry and doesn't really evoke any emotions. However, Suraj Sharma's narration adds real depth to his character. He's not just telling viewers how he caught fish, but also conveying his grim determination to survive. I'm sure it's easier for live actors to convey emotion than it is for words on a page, but I found myself caring far more about the characters in the movie than I ever did in the book.The movie is very faithful to the book. Perhaps surprisingly so. Ang Lee even kept the part in about Pi's conversion to Christianity and Islam. Again, I thought this was an improvement over the book. I thought the book spent far too much time in the beginning with random musings. The movie presents the same information but much more efficiently and beautifully.Overall, I'd imagine this movie will please fans of the book, as well as any viewers who appreciate a good yarn. Even if you didn't care for the book, I strongly suggest you give this a try.

reviewText: I enjoyed this film very much, and would be inclined to give it 5 stars - but it already has many 5-star revews...so I'll object to just a few things.  The opening sequence had beautiful 3D renderings and whetted my apetite for a 3D extravaganza - but the rest of the film wasn't so 3-dimensional as the opening. Fortunately, the core story was quite engrossing, well told, and visually exciting even without much use of the 3rd dimension.  I'll find fault with a metaphorical turn at the end, without mentioning plot details.  There was a brief exegesis in the film, which was in my opinion almost unnecessary, and too brief to make much of the metaphors.  That sent me to the book, which i hadn't read, where I found a much more detailed exegesis, which was interesting, but would have required more preparation in the earlier part of the story in order to make it possible for the themes to make sense.  That might have been a good idea, since there was a little puppy-love story that ended up being a loose end in the film.  That story could have been cut, in favor of stronger development of the vegetarian theme that IMO would add substance to the film. Nitpicking aside, this is one of the most interesting 3D films that I've seen - especially in its opening sequence!
summary: Very entertaining film that could be better

reviewText: All the hype! Story about faith! Computer generated gimmicks! Boring!Well, I went to my son's at Easter (He usually shows some after-dinner action flick with car chases.), he started his Blu-Ray, and "The Life of Pi" was emblazoned across his giant screen. I thought well, guess I'm stuck watching it. Within five minutes I was caught, spellbound, not only by the stunning beauty of the visual images but also by the flawless portrayals of the actors who were so natural that they didn't seem to be acting. Almost unawares I was so swept up with the story that I easily suspended my disbelief and was very close to tears at the utter beauty of what I was seeing. "The Life of Pi" is a cinematic masterpiece.Of many scenes of magnificent beauty, the one in which the golden sky blended into the sea simply blew me away. The film is so astonishing that I quickly forgot my bias against CGI.And I didn't mind the two endings. Whether the more prosaic version was the truth or not is irrelevant. For me, it provided a framework for the layered symbolism of the 'romantic' narrative.Ang Li's visual motifs are reminiscent of the verbal motifs of Greek tragedy. They penetrate deeply into the psychology of the characters. The blurring of the boundaries between illusion and reality--the very ambiguity of 'what actually happened'--makes me want to watch the picture over and over, as there is so much to savour.Happily, my son gave me the DVD as an Easter present!
summary: I did not want to see this film!

reviewText: I saw "Life of Pi" last night and absolutely loved it.  I still feel so overwhelmed by it, its visual splendor and the moving story that kept me involved for the whole time. The latest Ang Lee's film is beauty itself, and everyone involved in creation of such sparkling intelligent and classy entertainment deserves the highest praise and admiration for the work they've done.  I am sure that in two days, "Life of Pi" will receive majority of Oscars it is nominated for. It deserves them.I hesitated to see it because I did not think that the movie about a boy and a tiger stuck together in the middle of the ocean for months after the horrible shipwreck on the drifting lifeboat which the ferocious tiger first claimed as his territory and a makeshift inflatable raft chained to it which was Pi's fragile shelter would be so compelling and gripping but it was. Roger Ebert said that Life of Pi is "a miraculous achievement of storytelling and a landmark of visual mastery". I gladly agree with that. I simply can't find anything wrong with "Life of Pi." It is beautiful, profound and adventurous story of survival and understanding life with all it offers or throws at us.  It is life affirming even though it takes us along with Pi Patel through unspeakable hardship, losses, and deadly danger of indifferent and indomitable forces of nature's elements and wild creatures. And it manages to say a lot about faith and God without being over-simplistic, preachy or shoving religion in your face. It does help an atheist to understand the believers or at least to try. It also turns itself in unexpected direction when we thought we were in the end of the journey, reflects on the darkest corners of human nature and leaves the viewers asking questions on what they really want to believe and whether they are open to the possibility of miracle in life, in their lives. It is up to the viewers to choose the answer only they would be satisfied with.Peaceful beauty of Pondicherry, former French colony in India that surprisingly for me looked like a charming small French town, totally enthralled me in the beginning of the film that started as a typical coming of age story. Well, it is coming of age story but amazing on so many levels, spiritual, ethical, physical, religious, humanistic, testing the limits of what a human being can deal with and how it would shape him, his life, and his perception of life.  This is an experience, both movie watching and afterthought that will stay with me. What else can I ask for in a movie?  I've always respected and admired Ang Lee and found his movies exquisite. But "Life of  Pi" is without doubt his best work. Furious tiger, brave boy, magic journey, fascinating story - amazing movie.

reviewText: LIFE OF PI is visually stunning.  I observed tigers at close quarters for years as a volunteer at a preserve for big cats.  I was completely fooled by the CGI in the creation of "Richard Parker," although I began to catch on when the tiger did things it was difficult for me imagine a tiger doing, like climbing into a boat or catching and eating a live rat flung at it.  In terms of the story, these moves seemed possible, given the extreme circumstances the tiger was in.  I just wasn't sure of a real tiger, a Hollywood working animal, being successfully trained to do these things.The action at heart is an old-fashioned adventure tale of survival at sea with an unusual twist, told more with humor than desperation.  It strives to present the story as a spiritual one, but like the journalist (an off-putting performance by Rafe Spall.  Why would a stranger open up to this blank, boring boob?) I was underwhelmed by that aspect.  The "inspirational" thrust felt scrambled and overreaching, and once Pi is at sea, secondary.  I had only a tenuous idea by the end what all this was supposed to have to do with God.  Part of the problem may have been the sound in the all-important reveal Pi makes to the insurance investigators at the end.  Suraj Sharma's accent was too thick and his speech too fast for me to catch a lot of what he said.  Was it me, or was the sound poorly handled in this scene?  I've seen the film three times--still can't get it all.But I got the tiger.  Who hasn't felt at times trapped, abandoned, marooned, to face a proverbial tiger of some sort in our own lives completely on our own?  When Pi attributes his survival to Richard Parker for keeping him alert and active, the emotional truth resonated.  Overcoming a challenge to survival has been the making of many a man or woman.The greatness of this film lies not in its metaphors but in its awesome visual sweep.  I've never seen water look so crystal clear on screen.  Its appearance alone carries mystical implications.  The movie needs to be seen on the big screen to get its full meaning, for on the big screen the water not only thrills but illuminates.  Note that in the editorial review above, Kathleen Fennessey compares the brutal storm in this movie to TITANIC.  Puzzling, as there is no "horrific" storm in TITANIC.  Perhaps she meant to compare it to THE PERFECT STORM--whatever--but she's got her storms, and her movies, scrambled.  The water effects in LIFE OF PI range from being as shimmering and evocative as a Monet painting, to being a terrifying cataclysm.  TITANIC has nothing to compare with it.  In LIFE OF PI, the water is alive, one of the primary characters, and makes the movie come alive.
summary: Forget the Religion, Go With the Tiger

reviewText: What a tremendous film! The packaging states "The next Avatar", but "Life of Pi" is actually far superior. First of all, the cinematography is absolutely gorgeous. It's difficult to put into words just what a stunning picture this is. Director Ang Lee has far out-done himself.But what is a beautiful picture without a compelling story? And the story of Pi (and of Richard Parker) is indeed compelling. This movie is so gripping that you feel like you are part of the story. Starting off with Pi's childhood (and Richard Parker's early years as well) and moving into Pi's teenage years, this film tells a story for the ages. Solid acting combines with the majesty of nature to wrap you up in a narrative that is highly spiritual and suitable for family members of all ages. You leave this film feeling like a better person for having seen it.

reviewText: This was a really good effort at showing the dichotomy between man and beast.  It makes you think about life and what you would do in a similar situation.  Of course, sharing a boat with a Bengal Tiger is pure theatre (you wouldn't last a millisecond).  The movie was technically a winner.  I did not find any fault with the action scenes.  You really thought Richard Parker was only a few feet away.  Also, I liked that Ang Li did not go after any excessive bloody scenes that you would see in other productions.  I recommend this film to anyone old enough to understand.  Finally, I'm considering reading the book.  I would say this is very high praise.

reviewText: On one level, this is an action-adventure film about a boy and a tiger stranded on a boat.  But if it's approached that way, the beginning and ending of the film seem hard to reconcile.  This film presents a question that gets to the heart of religious faith in a way that both the believer and the non-believer can appreciate.  It's about all religions, not just one.  Pi is serially attracted to several of the world's major faiths, but the unique dogma of each is not the appeal.  It's the idea of religion that is the subject of the film.  Soon after the scene is set, Pi endures a terrifying ordeal involving a tiger and a lifeboat.  When it's over, he tells his story to skeptical investigators.  What has really happened here?  By posing the question the way it does the film offers an answer that tries to unravel the nature of faith and the purpose of belief.  I can think of far less interesting ways of spending two hours than watching this beautiful, challenging and thought-provoking film.The story of the making of the movie (in the blu-ray edition) is as fascinating as the movie itself.  Yes, it's (mostly) a digital tiger, but the technology simply does not reveal itself.  At all.  Side-by-side footage of the real tiger and the digital one are indistinguishable.  This is one case in which the work put into the making of the film is justified by the depth and beauty of the story.

reviewText: As is obvious from the number of rave reviews this film LIFE OF PI was are sounding success in the theaters when it was shown in 3D. There is no question but that the story, so well known over the past decades since the publication of the book of the same name by Yann Martel, draws everybody in, whether because of the indomitable spirit of our surviving hero or the religious aspects of the story.  Perhaps because of all the hoopla about director Ang Lee's manipulation of CGI effects and the endless interviews about the making of the film that make the final product (on DVD at least) seem so contrived and unreal that some viewers will find the end product less than satisfying a version of the novel. David Magee sculpted the screenplay from the novel and while that provides a lot of background about the character of Pi before the main event of the lost at see episode, it does seem disruptive at times and in this viewer's response robs the story form some of the poetry.The story has been summarized elsewhere as follows: `In Canada, a writer visits the Indian storyteller Pi Patel and asks him to tell a story. Pi tells the story of his life since he was a kid in Pondicherry, India and the origin of his nickname. One day, his father who owns a zoo tells his family that his business is not good and he had decided to move to Canada and sell part of the animals in the United States. They travel in a Japanese cargo ship with the animals and out of the blue, there is a storm followed by a shipwrecking. Pi survives in a lifeboat with a zebra, a orangutan, a hyena and a male Bengal tiger called Richard Parker. They are adrift in the Pacific Ocean and when the tiger is hungry, he eats the other animals. Soon Pi learns that he might find a way to feed and domesticate the tiger to survive.The character of Pi Patel is played for the most part by Suraj Sharma while his earlier years embodiments are shared by Ayush Tandon and Gautam Belur and the adult storyteller by Irrfan Khan. Pi's parents are played by Adil Hussain  and Gita Patel and his brother Ravi by, depending on age, Ayan Khan, Mohd Abbas Khaleeli, and Vibish Sivakumar,  Rafe Spall is the writer who will create the book from Pi's story, and for a few brief moments Gérard Depardieu plays a Cook on the ship.There are some very beautiful scenes of skies and waterscapes, but we are left wondering how much of this is carton created in the large studio tank that serves as the ocean. Some of Martell's original explanation of the various religions Pi adheres to are retained: they were the best part of the novel. Perhaps in 3D this film would have worked better. Grady Harp, March 13
summary: `I suppose the whole of life becomes an act of letting go, but what always hurts the most is not taking a moment to say goodbye'

reviewText: A spectacularly gorgeous movie, surreal and enchanting.  Some viewers have been critical of this film on grounds either religious or atheistic. It is worth appreciating that, like all the most intriguing stories, we can see in this film what we want.I've watched it three times now and would gladly watch it again.  IMO, it is a masterpiece to own and cherish.

reviewText: Wonderful and magical. And breathtaking.Unfortunately, I don't think it will do too well at the box office: the marketing for this movie has been so very atrocious I almost didn't watch it.Despite what the previews and promo posters might suggest, it is not yet another derivation of the Jungle Book as a motion picture (not that there is anything wrong with the Jungle Book or any movies or animations it inspired) or some politically correct cultural lesson on things that are Indian.What it is is a singular experience, and it is absolutely beautiful. I have been watching lots of movies ever since I was five years old, and I am having difficult time  coming up with another movie this captivating or visually stunning.I should be a bit ashamed to admit that I have found the majority of Ang Lee's movies rather boring (due to my attention deficit syndrome), but Life of Pi is NOT at all boring. Not even a little bit.This is the kind of movie you definitely need to watch on a big screen, so, folks, go see it while you still can!!!

reviewText: A well made movie worth watching in the theater, where I saw it, or at home on your screen via Amazon Instant Video.  With all the dime-a-dozen crap movies Hollywood is cranking out these days, this was refreshing to see.  It had depth and originality, providing the audience with stories of life-changing and soul-making significance.  Would someone who likes "only action" movies with lots of guns and cars like it? Probably not. But read the summary and watch the trailer, and if it piques your interest, I'd definitely recommend that you watch it.And if you're into the deeper mysteries of life, death, family, suffering, survival and liberation, the concepts of illusion,truth, perception and wisdom, you'd like this. Add to it the beautiful cinematography and you may be lost in its beauty as I was, mulling over the meanings of this and that with my friend for hours afterwards. I would buy it for $15  but not for $25. (The 25$ standard for me is industry-changing, movement-causing, classic-in-the-making movies - Shawshank Redemption, Matrix, Star Wars)If you do order it, try to drop the hype you've heard from your mind, including this review - you may not like it after all. I've noticed that when people say a movie is great so much, and then I see it, I am usually disappointed.  Release your expectations for a better movie experience. All the 5 star reviews may have hyped it up too much. I'm just saying it's worth the few bucks to rent it.
summary: Love it! Creative and beautiful, a great story told well

reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: This film is a marvellous adventure that is not done for little children who will get frightened but for children closer to 77 than to 7 years of age. But it is such a beautiful story that adults might like it too.Frightening like hell not on earth but on the Pacific Ocean. A shipwreck that sinks a cargo boat with only one survivor, a teenager hardly able to use a razor to shave and three animals from his father's zoo, animals that were being taken away to Canada to be sold: a Bengali tiger, a zebra and a hyena. The hyena is ignominious and it attacks the zebra on the lifeboat without even hesitating. The tiger is another story and the teenager is still another novel all by himself.But when you want to survive and you have in you the god that supports you, not a god with a trunk as long as a nose, or vice versa, not a god that dies on the cross for others, not a god that is hermaphrodite according to your capricious desires. Not at all. A god that is powerful in your soul, inspiring in your spirit, supportive in your mind and absolutely logical in your brain. Then you have the force with you and you can stand up against a Bengali tiger and tame it, and you can stamp your feet against the elements and organize your survival and that of "your" tiger.Then you have the mysterious island of Doctor Moreau, a carnivorous island that is also slightly cannibalistic. It is all sweet and nice in the day time but it turns flesh voracious at night. Can you imagine a tender teenager with no hairs on his face and a Bengali tiger: that's what I would call a meat ravenous predator's delicatessen treat.What is surprising but not so much if you know animals slightly is the tiger's taming. A wild animal will accept in some extreme conditions to be tamed when it feels you are the one who is going to help it survive if it lets you survive. Animals are intelligent and in extreme conditions they know their interest. I was told that many times in Sri Lanka where I used to walk in the jungle. I was told that if on your way a lion, a wild cat or an elephant comes to cross it towards its own destination, don't run, don't scream, don't make any brusque movement. The animal knew you were coming a long time before you ever knew it was there. If you don't block its way, if you do not produce the mammal hormone of fear that stinks like hell, if you look at the animal straight in the eyes and at the most slowly step back without getting your eyes away from its nor turning you back onto it, the animal will not attack you, and in fact most of the time the animal will avoid you and you will never see it though you might walk a few yards away from it.Animals are intelligent and they are not necessarily man's predators, even Bengali tigers.But when the animal will no longer need Pi it will just walk away back into its own animal life without even looking back. A wild animal can be tamed but it will never be the pet of a human being.The second lesson is that the insurance company of the ship does not accept that strange story with a tamed tiger and a carnivorous island, but it accepts quite well the story of four survivors with the odious cook who eats a rat, cuts up a sailor to catch fish, kills the mother of the hero and is killed by the hero himself. That sounds absurd in a way but human beings prefer a gross and totally inhuman story to a marvellous story about a wild animal that accepts to be tamed to survive and then walks away.The last idea or rather warning is that if some of you are secular minded to the point of negating any possible divinity or superior being or even superior force, don't go. This film is not about the gods we know in any religion but about the god that lives in your skull and animates you so strongly that it makes you able to survive in numerous situations without being a monster and using your fellow traveller as bait for sharks. Even if that fellow traveller is a wild Bengali tiger you have to tame it first. In fact if that god, like Jesus, you have him in your mind, brain, soul, spirit or whatever, dying on the cross becomes like an easy mission that you will not even try to evade or suspend or escape from.Too bad for those who consider any religious or mystic belief is an alienation and a fairy tale for dummies, because I know so many people who are beautiful for others and empathetic for any suffering just because in them they have the gem of that transcendence.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU
summary: My God is in me and I have a tiger in my soul

reviewText: Life of Pi is an emotional story, but well balanced. Tension builds but is released with some genuinely humorous lines, and none of it seems overplayed. If you've seen the trailer, you know that a boy ends up shipwrecked with a tiger. So - you'll spend the first bit of the movie wondering how this happens, and the second half of the movie wondering how he manages to make it out alive - that was enough to keep me keen to watch. And yes, he spends a long time in that boat, but that's how the story goes. After awhile I started to get antsy - when is he finally going to get out of that blasted boat?! That's just a snippet of the emotion that Pi must have endured. Any movie that makes me feel what the character feels is a winner in my book, and it happened throughout the movie.I am not a spiritual person and I definitely had to chew on the closing lines for a bit until I was satisfied with its meaning. If you don't want to reflect on life a bit, perhaps you should skip this film.My only complaint - fabulous acting and filming, but some of the CGI was distracting. Maybe it looked better in 3D at the theater?

reviewText: There are times I am out of step with popular trends; I was urged to read Yann Martel's enormously popular novel while it was on the best-seller list. Imagine my surprise when I discovered that I did not like it, in fact I disliked it! To me, the story of an Indian boy who is shipwrecked with a zebra, a hyena, an orangutan and a Bengal tiger is a bit much.With the astonishing Ang Lee as the director ("The Wedding Banquet," "Sense and Sensibility," "Brokeback Mountain," "Hulk," and "The Ice Storm"), things started looking up. As you can see from this sample of his work, this much-acclaimed artist never stays with one genre, never copies other filmmakers and never plays it safe. He rarely makes a PG film and I think this is his first 3D project.He did wonders with his cast:* Suraj Sharma (in his first film role) is Pi, an adventurous, inquisitive youngster. He has settled on being a vegetarian Hindu Muslim who embraces Catholic guilt, studies the Jewish Kabbalah, and wants to be baptized. He is convinced that religion is a big house with many rooms.* Irrfan Khan ("Slumdog Millionaire" and "The Amazing Spider-Man") is the adult Pi, who tells his spellbinding tale to a would-be author.* Rafe Spall ("Prometheus") is our incredulous listener, The Writer, who speaks for us as he expresses all the confusion, dismay and doubt that we in the audience naturally feel.* The tiger who plays Richard Parker is a seamless combination of real life and computer generated images. Brilliant!3D is rarely used this well, maybe you can get a new player from Amazon. The opening credit sequence that takes us through a small municipal zoo in India is a marvel, and the scenes with clear water are breathtaking: you can't tell water from air, so things seem to be floating above the earth. Kudos to Cinematographer Claudio Miranda for the dazzling effects! (We LOVED the flying fish!)The continuity is consistently good: as time goes by in the lifeboat, our hero and our tiger are visibly thinner, the tiger's teeth become greenish and both of them have dry unhealthy hair. The shipwreck is tough to see, but we don't have to watch carnivores kill their lunch, and when Pi finally brains a fish, he weeps and apologizes to it. Don't show this to toddlers, but from ten years old and up, I think a child can handle it.In my opinion, this was much better than the book! (But I still hate the island!)

reviewText: I HATE this movie! NO SPOILERS! Notice that I didn't use the past tense, hated, but the present tense, hate. My loathing of this film is an active and ongoing thing. Life of Pi starts off nicely enough with an interesting story that you think is going in one direction and then whip lashes you in another... Fair enough I suppose, I don't mind being surprised. What offended me the most was the extreme violence depicted in the film. Had I lived back in the days of the Roman Empire, I would NOT have been front row center when they brought the animals out for slaughter. Yet, for the entire second half of the movie, we are asked to sit and watch the surviving animals from a shipwreck kill and eat one another in a tiny lifeboat. If you've seen the film you'll know that it's all OK because of the twist ending. I found the computer generated imagery to be sadly lacking and the entire movie feels like a sick trick that is played on the viewer. I HATE THIS MOVIE!
summary: Didn't like this film, HATED it in fact...

reviewText: This is a nice flick.  To me, the symbolism was overdone.  The ending left me a bit cold.  Visually, very beautiful, but all animation. I'm not sure, with all the superb animation and computer graphics that exist in the world these days, why this movie was so chatted-up.  I found it to be a faux-myth without much substance at all.  With all that said, it's worth the rental fee, perhaps a good purchase.  If you want to know 'everything' that can be done on a computer, then it's worth it as well.  A little disappointed.

reviewText: I missed this movie when it was in the theaters, so I was eager to see it as a rental.  I had heard the hype, and I was expecting to be blown away by this film.  On only rare occasions in my life have I been let down to this extent.I borrowed the movie from my local library at the cost of one dollar. It wasn't worth it. The whole time I was watching it I was thinking, "What the hell is the point of this movie?? Is it going to get better any time soon??" I had to fight to stay awake. It was two hours of my life that went irretrievably down the drain.I am absolutely at a loss to understand how any sane person could rate this movie anything higher than one star. What a profoundly ridiculous premise:  the kid is in a life boat adrift on the ocean along with a tiger, a zebra, an orangutan, and a hyena who take turns getting "lost" under a tarp that covers the front half of the lifeboat. They somehow magically appear at various times to provide material for each scene. One can almost hear the director out of sight saying, "Okay, cue the tiger!" The hyena and tiger pose an obvious threat to Pi's existence, but he easily could have just charged them when they were near the edge of the boat and...viola!...into the drink they go. No more threat. Oh wait, I forgot. That would make sense in his struggle for survival, but this is really an utterly pointless movie.

reviewText: Ang Lee does it again with this tale of a young man and his survival of a shipwreck only to be trapped on a lifeboat with a live tiger. I must admit that I am not at all familiar with the book, so I bring no book-laden expectations to the film. I saw this film strictly on the basis of a few trailers I saw that intrigued me. I love the visual splendor of the tiger, and the menace of the tiger at close quarters was absolutely terrifying. The great cosmic meaning of the film may have escaped me, but I  was transfixed at the sight of this beautiful and deadly beast and the young man playing a cat and mouse game with him in the lifeboat. I was well entertained, and am not worried if I should have had a profound insight and did not. The film is like a moving breathing work of art, and it captured my attention for every minute of it's length, which is something that I can't say about many films these days. If you enjoyed PI, you might also considerBeasts of the Southern Wild.If you have a fascination with wild animals, especially tigers, grab this DVD asap! If you want the deeper meaning, I'm sure someone will explain it to you until your eyes glass over.

reviewText: Though I'd give this film 4 and 1/2 stars due to a few very minor quibbles with pacing, I'm happy to give it 5 well-deserved stars on Amazon because it is such a relief to see a big movie of this caliber of quality and craftsmanship in 2013. Yes, there are still some fine movies being made (even some of the "tent-pole" blockbusters are satisfying) but 'Life of Pi' is as rewarding and, in its own way, as awe-inspiring as any of the current epic releases helmed by bigger budgets and bigger names. Under genius Ang Lee's impeccable direction the uplifting and absolutely heart-breaking tale of Pi and Richard Parker is brought to spectacular CGI "life" with an added and unmistakable dose of dignified Humanity so lacking today, not only in our movies but across our culture. The film is essentially a parable, in my opinion, about the perception of truth and how the human spirit creates magic out of unspeakable tragedy in the attempt to draw meaning and find redemption where there is little of either to be found. Is it the story of a young Indian boy adrift in a lifeboat on the ocean for 227 days with a Bengal tiger as his simultaneous enemy and companion? That, dear moviegoer or movie-watcher, is for YOU to decide. The exhilarating thing about 'Life of Pi' is that you will be amazed by it, and you will find yourself thinking about it. Most truly. Kudos to Ang Lee and everyone involved with the meticulous and admirable execution of this very special film experience. For those who first warmed to the tale via the  book by Yann Martel, rest assured that the spirit of that classic work is painstakingly preserved and adapted with humility and no small amount of splendor. A feast for the eyes, the senses and, especially, for the heart. Adults will hold this film dear, but if you have kids over age 9 (or maybe 12) get them to watch it with you. I have a feeling they will never forget it. It's actually comforting to know that films this lavish and yet so spiritually pure are still being green-lighted by the deservedly beleaguered Big Hollywood Machine. Hope springs eternal, I guess.
summary: Visually Sumptuous, Compelling and Truly Magical

reviewText: Ang Lee rocks.The remarkable Taiwanese director adds the crown jewel in an already lifetime-hall-of-fame-worthy arsenal of brilliant films (Crouching Tiger, The Ice Storm, the Wedding Banquet, Eat Drink Man Woman, Sense and Sensibility, Brokeback Mountain...I mean, really....what can Ang Lee NOT do?).  No other living director - and very few ever - comes close to the vision Lee delivers with Life of Pi.  From the indelible images of animals in a zoo that flood our field of vision over the opening credits to its final moments in a questionable raft riding rough pounding seas, the maestro creates a singular unified story for the ages...and all ages too.  Hard to imagine as a novel I never read, the book was not expected to yield such a bounty of sheer beauty and natural punch, but holy cow, it does!  Its a blockbuster And then some.  Even on DVD.  Pi is the sort of film that should be on permanent display once a week at least at a theater near you.

reviewText: I will admit that when i first saw the trailer for this, i misjudged this movie. I thought to myself "what a ridiculous looking  movie." But recently I found out I was completely dead wrong about this Film. I do not know where to begin. Suraj Sharma plays the title character Pi and he does it realistically. Pi is everything I would hope to be in his situation: brave, courageous, and daring. This movie also proves (and does a really good job at it) that help can come from the most unlikely ally. That being said, the storyline is top notch in this film and it is deeply moving. The supporting cast is good, but the surprise in this film (and i think many will agree) are the effects and visuals. Ang Lee Deserves not only a tip of the hat, but in my opinion he deserves a standing ovation for making such an enjoyable film. Quoting one of the lines from the film "I was told you have a story that would make me believe in God,"  And in my honest opinion, this film has done that and so much more. 5 stars

reviewText: Ang Lee's presentation of the Life of Pi was a delight to me. I loved this book when I first read it, and I had trouble getting it out of my head for months.  My experience with movies made from books that I have loved has been mixed - some of the movies have been enjoyable and some have been disappointing, all for many and varied reasons, so I settled down in front of the flat screen TV to watch Life of Pi with my best open mind.Although it has been a few years since I read the book, the movie brought it back to me in waves of memories.  The film was visually stunning to me (You must stream this movie in HD to be stunned), and I didn't feel cheated by not having it in 3D, since the 5.1 surround sound was enough realism for me.  The tiger was magnificently created and was as real to me as any real tiger could be.  The love that Pi and Richard Parker shared developed as tenderly as any love story could, and showed the reality of human misperception of "taming" a wild animal. Pi was convincinly played as an adorable, if somewhat irascible, young man and as an engaging, deeply thoughtful adult.As with the book, the movie left me totally satisfied with the experience of the story, and with renewed questions about which version of Pi's story was really real. As with the book, in the end it didn't matter to me, because the story was so engaging, so entertaining and so lovely.

reviewText: A Beautiful Masterpiece !!! While it starts out very slow and boring it gets exciting and scary and dramatic - very dramatic !!!. Ok sents their is only two things about this film that i didn't enjoy lets start out with that ok lets begin. The beginning of this movie well lets say the first um 30 minutes of the movie were pretty ugg slow. I was bored out of my mine with it i swear. It was so slow and boring that i thought about leaving the theater and seeing Red Dawn but i didn't. The beginning was just um well it didn't fit with the rest of the film and was not very nessesary to me. I mean all of that story about religion and falling for a girl for about five minutes then leaving her i mean come on was all of that nessesary really???? No it was not. The acting in the beginning was great but all together unnessesary. It was boring with only the part with the tiger being interesting. But after that half an hour the film started to get great, i mean really really good. The huge storm scene with the ship was epic, it was really, really cool. Actually there were lots of scenes that i found amazingly beautiful like the part with the whale and the animals who looked infact real but they were not they were animated but they were done so well they looked real.The second thing that i didn't enjoy was the removal of Tobey Maguire. Tobey Maguire was like way better at his acting as the writer then Rafe Spall was way better and sents the director decided to cut tobey like 2 months from the films release they had to like rush the reshoots and it made those scenes look well bad it was sad they cut him. It was a really bad move. Ok the good stuff well you already heard about the beauty in the film but i will still talk more about it, the acting in particuler the newcomer Suraj Sharma who to me did a realistic and great preformence, the cast,The director , the animation, the scenery , and everything else. Ok almost every scene int his film looks like a diamond all sparkly and well pollashed, i'm not stretching the point they made every scene look better then the scene before it was just so pretty and man did i want to eat it up loved it. It was just so cool. The acting was very very good outside of Rafe Spall everybody looked like they really were enjoying filming of Life of Pi, Suraj Sharma in particuler gave a 101 % in trying he was great i loved him. I thought sad to say i thought he was going to give a really bad preformence but when i saw the film he was just amazing. Man Suraj Sharma has real talent in acting he does i hope the best for him. In the future i hope he is able to get more good leading film roles cause he deserves them he really does which leads me into my next conversation about the casting. Man i'm sad to say that now adays directors only cast well known actors in their movies like Will Ferral or Kevin James but the director who is really greatchose a cast of well newcomers who had little to no acting experience which worked for everyone but for the cutting of tobey who we already talked about.I believe directors should cast no more then 2 well known actors and put them in supporting roles with little advertisment on them sort of like Alice in Wonderland but they advertised the Mad Hater who was played by Johnny Depp like he was the main charactor and put him on the posters but they rarly advertised alice who IS the main charactor and she is not even on the poster i mean whats up with that its really stupid!!! The director was very good with casting which leads me into my next subject on the director. I rarly talk about directors when i review a film but i believe this director deserves some praise from me. The director was Ang Lee he was outstanding he was. The way he cast the film , produced the film , and brought the charactors onto the big screen , were amazing he is now in my top five best directors list he is, i loved him, he is great !!! The visual effects of the film are top notch. reviewText: Life of Pi asks big questions but leaves audiences with few answers. This latest Ang Lee movie is an adaptation of the eponymous novel by Yann Martel, which already had a large readership before Lee announced the upcoming film release. Life of Pi tells the story of Piscine Molitor Patel who grows up in India, where his father owns a zoo. He changes his name to "Pi" to avoid jokes about his name's homophonic similarities to the slang word for urination. The story could be divided into three acts: 1) his years growing up in India, 2) the shipwreck and his life as a castaway, 3) his reflections on his experiences.The film begins with Pi speaking with a freelance writer. Pi's uncle told this writer that Pi had quite a story to tell and so the writer came to investigate. The film is Pi's narrative.Though growing up a Hindu, Pi explores Christianity and Islam and finds admirable things in all there. In one scene he is engaged in praying to Allah on a prayer mat; the next shows him crossing himself before he eats. This sequence of shots, with the adult Pi narrating his exploration of religion, confronts the audience immediately with an "all paths lead to God" form of spirituality that is reflective of the contemporary milieu and the philosophy of John Hick. At this point, Lee has given the film profound religious dimensions.Pi's father decides to move the family and bring the zoo animals along to sell in North America. On their way, a storm hits the cargo ship and Pi ends up being the sole survivor after being lowered in a lifeboat. The lifeboat also holds a hyena, an orangutan, a wounded Zebra, and a Bengal tiger named "Richard Parker." The hyena ends up eating the zebra alive, followed by killing the orangutan, only to be eaten by Richard Parker. Pi ends up fishing to feed the tiger so that he won't decide to eat Pi. They end up coming to an island, which they then leave after discovering that its ecosystem was carnivorous. The lifeboat ends up being washed ashore on the Mexican coast.After they reach land, Richard Parker journeys into the jungle and leaves no trace behind. Representatives of the cargo ship owners visit Pi in the hospital to learn why the ship sank, but instead get Pi's extraordinary story of survival. They refuse to believe it, so Pi tells a metaphorical story whereby the Zebra is a wounded sailor, the orangutan is his mother, the hyena is the ship's callous cook, and Richard Parker is Pi himself.Pi asks the writer which version of the saga he prefers. The animal version, he replies. Pi gives him the report filed by the ship company representatives, which reads that Pi held the record for shipwreck survivor longest at sea, and simply notes that he was accompanied by a Bengal tiger. We are left to interpret that comment ourselves. Does this last note demonstrate that there was evidence of a Bengal tiger on the ship and hence lends credence to Pi's story? Or does it merely indicate that the company representatives preferred the fantastical version?Somehow the audience is expected to come full circle--the beginning of the film asks questions about God's existence and the human spiritual experience and the movie ends with Pi uttering cryptic lines that are supposed to have answered these questions. I left the theater rather unsatisfied, not because there were no answers, but because Lee failed to even provide the connection between the three parts of the film. We moved from big questions in the first part to an end that jumped to a vague interpretation of the castaway experience.The clear import of the closing scene is that we can choose to view reality as mundane and material, or we can see it in all its manifold beauty that whispers the existence of God as corroborated by mindboggling providence. There is something inherent in us that wants to believe the latter and, lucky for us, the latter is true. If anything, Life of Pi is an argument for the existence of God based on the experience of beauty--whether it is physical beauty (the trailer shows jaw-dropping scenes of splendor that do not disappoint) or the beauty of storytelling.Life of Pi oddly lacks a theodicy. It doesn't address the pain of why Pi's parents had to die and why there's a Darwinian food chain in the lifeboat. The story might be trying to go one-step more and relegate these painful episodes to being part of the conflict--a necessary component to any good story. And that's what we're wrapped up in: the story of the universal soul. This is intellectually rooted in Hindu-Buddhistic views of cyclical history that can celebrate such a story of suffering without demanding justice from a higher power.To sum it up, the appetizer in the beginning and the dessert at the end tasted good, but the main course seemed completely unrelated to either. The whole time spent eating the main course was similar to an idyllic and eye-popping version of Tom Hanks's Castaway that singularly focused on survival. I have not read the book, so I'm not sure if Martel does a better job with this, but Lee's adaptation left something to be desired.[This review was published previously on Schaeffer's Ghost ([...])]

reviewText: Without the stunning visual images in the "adrift at sea" section of the movie, the viewer might despair of Pi's fate. Yet this movie is really about his journey in spirit. After having to leave India with his family, the boy becomes the lone human survivor after the cargo ship they were taking passage to North America is scuttled in a typhoon off the Philippines. In India they had been the operators of a small zoo. Some of their animals made the trip and 3 in particular survived the initial shipwreck. Some of the spiritual dynamics introduced including Krishna are brought out as Pi learns to deal with his ferocious companion, a Bengal tiger named Richard Parker and as the days lengthen to months at sea with little hope of survival we see how he envisions the world of the sea in fantastic luminous images. He first lands on a strange island which is hospitable by day and hostile by night by virtue of pure waters turning acidic by night. Later he washes up in Mexico where his longtime companion tiger just calmly walks into the forest without a look back. This upsets him and then a strange twist occurs when he is asked by Japanese authorities to account for his being the only survivor of the wrecking of their cargo ship. His story is too fantastic for them so he tells them another one which is more sinister yet more plausible. The allegory is caught by his listener as he retells the story many years later. The spiritual lesson is what do you wish to believe, the boy floating across the Pacific with a tiger or a boy who escaped evil doers.
summary: A spectacle of a boy's journey

reviewText: I think this is an excellent and gripping film and worthwhile seeing for older children, teenagers and adults. Most of all, it is about a young Hindu boy's spiritual journey, and for me the main theme is how he grew to give complete surrender to God for control of his present and future. There is a wonderful balance of humour with the tragedy and suspense in the film. The joke about his name is slightly vulgar, but funny all the same, and so typical of some little boys. I totally understand some people's concerns about the different religions mentioned, and there is a slight leaning toward the idea that all religions are equal. However, as his father says in the movie--you have to choose one road and to choose all of them is to have nothing!There are many Christian references contained in the film. These include Pi saying that he found Christ, the priest quotes John 3:16, Pi is shown praying and seems to pray to accept Christ, he says grace before every meal and says amen, mention is made of Jesus' Sacrifice and how He died for the sins of many when He had not sinned, the fact that he refers to himself as Catholic first, and his request to be baptized. The way I take it is that he still has his East Indian culture, but identifies himself as a Christian.It's a movie that can be appreciated on many different levels, and there is symbolism in the story, if you choose to see it. I wish I could get some other people's feelings on the symbolism of the tiger. To me he was representative of the boy's family with whom he was on a life journey, but they didn't get to say goodbye and to say thank you for all they had meant to each other. The tiger gave him life in many ways, and so did his family.As you're probably gathering, this movie can be taken in many different ways. This is not a movie for young children due to the graphic nature of the ship wreck, some of the animal deaths, and how scary it is in some places because of the tiger living with him on the boat in the middle of the ocean. Also, take your motion sickness pills before going. After about an hour on the sea, I really started to feel it, ha ha. The 3D effects and cinematography are really quite stunning and if this movie doesn't win some Oscars I will be very much surprised.I cannot say enough about the performance of Suraj Sharma who gave a brilliant acting performance. He is so believable as Pi and with this being his first film, I'd say he is a natural actor. Pi's romance is absolutely adorable as well.  As a Canadian I loved the Canadian reference to Winnipeg. Apparently the writer of the book is a Canadian.  I'd highly recommend this film which is brilliantly directed.
summary: Excellent & Thought Provoking Film With Canadian Connection! :)

reviewText: A young boy's family is moving their zoo animals from India to Canada when a storm sinks their freighter.  The only survivors are Pi, a hyena, a zebra, and a tiger named Richard Parker, who find themselves in a lifeboat in the middle of the ocean.On the plus side, I liked that the movie was faithful to the book. The photography and special effects were breathtaking; director Ang Lee has created a dreamy, magical, and stunningly beautiful world. The CGI tiger was excellent; I couldn't tell when he was drawn and when he was real. The soundtrack is lovely.On the down side, I found myself glancing at my watch at times, wondering when it would be over. The pace was too slow for me and I think it would have been an even better movie had 15 minutes been cut from it.The acting was outstanding and fans of the wonderful book will not be disappointed.
summary: A boy, a tiger, and a boat.  Or not.

reviewText: I sat on the sofa with my husband and teen aged children. I knew Life of Pi had won awards but I needed to read reviews before deciding whether to watch it. I read the reviews on Amazon before watching this movie. In fact I usually come to Amazon before making a final decision on a film. The part that baffles me is the negative reviews of this film. I don't understand why anyone would have compared this to Avatar or why anyone after watching the entire film would bother bringing Avatar up. The only reason I can fathom as to why anyone would dislike this movie is if they didn't understand it. And that in itself baffles me too. Visually, this movie was stunning. Period. The cinematography and effects were gorgeous. Gorgeous not like Avatar...gorgeous like Life of Pi. The two are two very very different types of movie. But by the end of this movie I knew that it was not just a film for entertainment sake or about visual effects. It was human, raw, and frankly the story isn't about the tiger, it's about the boy who survived. The story is his. No matter what the real ending is, matters not. What matters is that we as humans face sometimes the most unfathomable trials and challenges and how we handle them is entirely up to us. When I finished watching this and I was done wiping my tears away, I knew I wanted to see it again. Somehow I felt like the lessons in the story weren't all going to be caught on the first try. It is worth watching again for the parts I may have missed. I was in awe of the cast and how effortlessly they played their parts. There were times when I laughed, times when I cried, times when I cringed and that is what a movie experience is supposed to be. No, that is what story telling is supposed to be. This film most definitely deserved academy awards. And I'll end this review...this very simplistic review with saying that I feel sorry for those that hated this movie. They missed out on the powerful message and the beautiful story. I can only be glad for myself that I got to experience Pi's story. I know I was transformed. .
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Life Of Pi" is brilliant! This is how the story goes: Based on the best-selling novel by Yann Martel, is a magical adventure story centering on Pi Patel, the precocious son of a zoo keeper. Dwellers in Pondicherry, India, the family decides to move to Canada, hitching a ride on a huge freighter. After a shipwreck, Pi finds himself adrift in the Pacific Ocean on a 26-foot lifeboat with a zebra, a hyena, an orangutan and a 450-pound Bengal tiger named Richard Parker, all fighting for survival.The cast led by Suraj Sharma (as Pi) & Irrfan Khan (as adult Pi) is brilliant. The (Oscar-winning) directing by Ang Lee (who also produced) is brilliant. The screenplay by David Magee (based on the novel) is brilliant.The (Oscar-winning) music by Mychael Danna is brilliant. The (Oscar-winning) cinematography by Claudio Miranda is brilliant. The film editing by Tim Squyres is brilliant. The casting by Avy Kaufman is brilliant. The production design by David Gropman is brilliant. The art direction by Al Hobbs, Ravi Srivastava, James F. Truesdale & Dan Webster is brilliant. The set decoration by Terry Lewis & Anna Pinnock, set designs by Sarah Contant, Jim Hewitt & Easton Michael Smith is brilliant. The costume design by Arjun Bhasin is brilliant. The special effects supervised by Jean-Martin Desmarais, coordinated by John Rosengrant, Alan Scott & Lindsay MacGowan is brilliant. The (Oscar-winning) visual effects supervised by Paul Graff, Susan MacLeod, Guillaume Rocheron & Bill Westenhofer, coordinated by Dana Lynn Bennett, Blair Brownlee, Rebecca Brookman, Bryce Brecheisen, Celine Chew, James Cochrane, Gloria Cohen, Sonia D'Costa, Sheila Giroux, Ankit Gokani, James Grummitt, Chad Hudson, Eric Kimelton, Monet Monge, Molly Pabian, Brett Skaggs, Judy Webster & Bryan Wengroff is brilliant. The stunts coordinated by Charles Croughwell & John Stoneham Jr. is brilliant.This is a brilliant and well-crafted (as well as, well-made) film that is entertaining and intriguing that is different and interesting. This is also a visually beautiful treat that is beautiful either in 3D or 2D. Ang Lee has made another interesting and well-made film that is definitely one of his best movies of his career. This is also one of the best films of the holiday season and of the year. This is also a film that should be remembered come the awards season.

reviewText: If Frank Darabont's The Shawshank Redemption, James Cameron's Titanic, and Alfred Hitchcock's Lifeboat made you believe in the power of story, then so shall Ang Lee's Life of Pi by way of Yann Martel's book of the same title. Like Shawshank Redemption, the protagonist undergoes physical, mental, and emotional damage that will either kill him or make him stronger although transformed. Like Titanic, a ship goes down and carries away family, safety, and security upon its descent. Like Lifeboat, an unusual mix of characters share tight, claustrophobic, treacherous quarters in a bid to survive at sea. Life of Pi is a beautiful story well-matched with breathtaking cinematography, visual effects, and sound design. Based upon the strength of these separate elements operating together in excellence, Ang Lee won Best Director.Truly fantastic is the powerful allegorical revelation of God in science based upon two interpretations of horrific, life-changing tragedies in the world of the protagonist a teenage boy. A storm at sea throws Pi either into the hands of God, or Mother Nature, or as Pi would have it--both. Driven to his physical, mental, and emotional limits while adrift for 227 days in the Pacific Ocean, Pi addresses the strains on his capacities by adapting to his horrific reality via spiritual, religious, scientific means, or perhaps cognitive dissonance.Some may view Pi's interpretations of his reality as opposite and therefore impossible. Others may view Pi's interpretations as complementary, and entirely reasonable. One step further and the viewer may even choose to accept the concept of God as the creator of all science and all scientific laws, God as the creator of evolution. Two steps further and the viewer may understand that logic and reason remain entirely compatible with religion and spiritualism. After two viewings, the only surprise that remains with Life of Pi is that it did not win the award for adapted screenplay.
summary: If The Shawshank Redemption, Titanic, and Lifeboat moved you...

reviewText: Unfortunately I did not enjoy this movie as much as so many others did.  As a matter of fact I was hugely disappointed.  A friend of mine had encouraged me to see this movie, and rather gushed over it.  "It was so amazing", she said.The strange thing about this movie is it really resembledThe Tree Of LifeandThe Fountain. Although The Life Of Pi definitely had a more developed story than the other two.I won't go into too much detail, I will however give my customary parent of children warning:  The movie plays on Pi's name where they change it to "P!ssing".  And they say "P!ssing" over and over.  Over twenty times.  They just won't let it die.  Kids, adults, narrator, everyone is saying it.  Its not that funny and the thick Indian/Hindu dialect makes it so hard to even understand the joke, all you hear is "P!ssing"!Then there is the scene where Pi is standing with his back to the camera and you see him urinating on the tarp of the boat.  The animated lion then turns his rear to Pi and sprays Pi in the face with urine. Necessary to the movie? No. Big movie execs thinking the adults will love it? Yes.And that's the end of my parents with children warning.  Unless of course you want me to cover the many animals that are attacked and die.  But I am sure others have warned you of that.I believe the story could have been more believable, understanding, or even more enjoyable had they not had the weirdness intermingled in it.  You never know if the story is real or if he is hallucinating.  Even at the end when he is explaining to the investigators what really happened on the ship, he tells two different stories.  Supposedly one is true, but they are both so far out you really don't know which one is true at all.The human acting was pretty good, however the animation of all of the animals really took away from the story rather than enhance it.Overall, I would never recommend this movie to anyone. Friend or enemy. I struggle with giving it one star even, but since it wasn't near as bad as The Tree of Life I am going to up it a star.  I wish I could understand and enjoy these "great" movies as much as everyone else does.  But I just. don't. get. it.
summary: Not My Favorite Piece Of Pi

reviewText: Dont get me wrong, Pi (as an adult) appears to be a wonderful person - probably a good father and husband and teacher. However, if (as the story portrays) he was touched as deeply by the desolate and constantly life-challenging circumstances at sea with the tiger, Richard Parker, he would (as an adult) be the biggest conservationist on the planet based out of India saving every last (of the few) wild bengal tigers. Because he isn't, I am ultimately left at the end feeling like 'has he really learned anything?'I recommend leaving the theater moments after Pi tells Richard Parker "we are dying." Because in the real world, more often than not, there are no hollywood endings - especially for bengal tigers.

reviewText: "Life of Pi" starts pleasantly, though is confusing.  It has the potential of being something quite thought provoking.  But, the thing quickly degrades into a hellish experience that will leave scarred memories, images that may well remain with the viewer for some time to come.The mindless, idiotic fool that is the central character fumbles his way onto a life boat while intentionally wandering around on the deck of a ship that is struggling to stay afloat in typhoon conditions.  There are zoo animals confined on this ship, which are depicted as drowning below deck while the ship is slowly doing down.  People and animals suffer miserably, and you get to see it!While everyone in your living room is begging you to please stop this miserable agony of a "movie"; you hold on hoping this garbage will improve eventually.  Then you get to see a hyena attack, and mutilate a zebra while the coward is standing in the lifeboat with a ten foot oar in his hands, just looking at the butchery with flies buzzing in & out of his cavernous pie-hole!I slammed the stop button on the remote, and found myself desperately wishing I could grab that oar and do to the fool what he should have done to the hyena!If you have children, or adults with sensitive demeanors in your family, be sure to avoid this ravishing torture at all costs!!

reviewText: This is a very unusual story about a spiritual young man who survives an incredible ordeal at sea. When you get to the story's end, you may find yourself going over it in your mind for days, working out the details. Visually it is gorgeous and awe inspiring at times. A friend who saw it on the big screen said it was even more impressive, and I can see why. But it carries over pretty well to the tv screen as well. Parts of the story are full of adventure as young Pi deals with the tiger on board and brutal storms at sea. I think this movie was difficult to market. It is not a story for little kids about animals, etc.. It is pretty heavy duty philosophically and spiritually. Some of the events may even be too disturbing for young children. Maybe 12 and up or a bit younger for mature kids. If you like to think, if you enjoy philosophy, if you seek God, if you are open to the stories and perspectives of others, you will enjoy this film. It is very well done.
summary: Thought provoking, beautiful, spiritual and exciting!

reviewText: The 411 by Maria:In it's most basic form the movie is about Pi Patel, the only human survivor after his parents commission a ship to move their zoo from India to Canada. Along with Pi is an orangutan, a hyena, a zebra that broke it's leg when it feel into the life boat and an adult Bengal Tiger (who is named Richard Parker).After the other animals are killed by tiger, Pi and the Tiger learn to coexist on and off the life boat until Pi is rescued in Mexico 227 days after the ship went down.OK...now that I gave you that very brief summary, let's get into how and why I liked it so much. The movie is exquisitely done with amazing cinematography and CGI effects. I truly love how beautiful it was and wish I had seen it in 3D!Pi played by Suraj Sharma as the shipwrecked younger Pi and later Irrfan Khan as older Pi, is amazingly resourceful as he struggles to keep himself and Richard Parker alive.My husband says it reminded him of Tom Hanks Castaway, I can see why he would say that but visually, it is way above Castaway.Very cool effects!

reviewText: I have noticed some reviews that touch upon the ending of the movie with anger and frustration.  Most ignore the ending all together, as though this were purely a nature or adventure film.  Can one ignore the last half hour of a movie such as The Sixth Sense?  Or, The Usual Suspects, which has a similar ending?Clearly this is a movie (and novel) about believing, or not believing in God.  The young Pi had a horrible, traumatic experience that he could not (or did not WANT to) remember.  He had to assist in the operation of a sailor with an infected leg, saw the dead sailor being used as bait for food, saw his mother die, saw his mother eaten by sharks, and, then, had to kill a man (the cook) himself.  Who would not want to create an alternative story--one in which God intervenes to make things more bearable?And, yet, at the end Pi asked people to choose which story they prefered.  This is tantamount to asking someone if they want to believe in reality, which can be cruel, or believe in God, which can be comforting.  That is what this entire movie is about!  Does that make it less appealing than a good adventure story?  Obviously, the answer must be "YES" for most people, based on the reviews I have read.

reviewText: This tale deals with a boy in 1950s India who finds God in many forms and is then persuaded by his father during a violent incident with a Bengal Tiger that God does not quite exist as suspected. Years pass and then when he loses his entire family aboard a sea vessel and that he's stranded on a lifeboat with a ferocious tiger that he once again "sees" God in many forms.What follows is up to your opinion. Some would call it a spiritual journey and others would name it a massive hallucination to deal with the loss of his family and the horrors he faces. The beauty of this film is that either interpretation is correct. Too often these types of films pick one solid belief and then fight for it at the expense of other interpretations.Yes, that nasty chef was Gerard Depardieu.If you want something different yet engaging this is worth the price of admission but be warned it drags a bit in the middle hence my not so perfect grade for STORY/PLOTTING/EDITING.Pay attention to the very ending or you're going to miss a very important point or two about the entire film.Based on a best-selling novel by Yann Martel this picture had a budget of $120M and as of this writing has made over $451M in the theaters.The Golden Globes awarded this film Best Score and nominated it for Best Picture and Best Director and Best Motion Picture --- Drama. The Academy Awards (who have yet to issue their awards as of this writing) nominated it for, well, almost everything: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Cinematography, Film Editing, Sound Editing, Production Design, Sound Mixing, Visual Effects, Original Score and Original Song.STORY/PLOTTING/EDITING: B; CHARACTERS/DIALOGUE: B to B plus; SOUND/MUSIC: B plus to A minus; CINEMATOGRAPHY: A minus; THEMES/FOCUSES: B plus; OVERALL GRADE: B plus; WHEN WATCHED: mid January 2013 (at the movies).

reviewText: The ocean, nature, life-boat, animals, and disastrous fate of a family aspiring for new life in a new world, all constitute solid foundation to a wonderful cinematic play. Such joy of living at the mercy of beautiful, vast, deadly ocean on the big screen was minimized or undermined by the trivial dialogue between a writer and a story teller trying to explain how he got his name PI, how the ship sank, or how the Japanese investigators were puzzled by his narration.Even though the movie lasted over 2 hours, in 3D, the portion of the teller and the writer about the youth of the teller in India and his family affairs after his survival were boring, immaterial, and spoiled the great and exotic events of surviving on a boat with a hungry untamed tiger.There were plenty of scenes that should have been added to the transport of animals from India to the Japanese ship shat could have made the movie a marvelous piece of art and which were omitted by the moviemaker. Instead, trivial kitchen table discussions killed the joy of fighting the elements of merciless ocean.Very intense and long moments of rough waves, winds, and water sunk a ship loaded with people, animals, and great hope for better life crashed with the sinking ship. That was followed by many marvelous events of flying fish, whale attack causing gigantic shock waves in water, highways of playful dolphins, and exotic island, rich with animals, vegetation, and peculiar chemistry.The greatest cinematic play were vividly demonstrated in many chapters. A hungry vicious hyena victimizes a zebra and orangutan,never rests until attacked by a Bengali tiger. The actions of the three animals was truly impressive, appearing very real. The tiger performed magnificent job of high precision, pride, and immensely powerful motion, in health and sickness.The movie is a must see.Mohamed F. El-Hewie
summary: Could have been gloriously better without the documentary portions of the story
