reviewText: Supposedly un-filmable, this fantastical tale of a teenager from India surviving at sea for weeks, alone but for a Bengal tiger is a remarkable piece of filmmaking.  The movie begins with an adult Piscine (Pi) Patel (Irfan Khan) relating a potential story for a book to be written by a friend of a friend (Rafe Spall).He tells of him and his family leaving India and their zoo for Canada to start over.  They have crated up numerous animals for the long voyage on a Japanese cargo ship.  During a violent storm the ship sinks, but through some fortune, Pi (Suraj Sharma) has managed to land on a life boat along with an injured zebra, a disoriented Orangutan and an ornery Hyena.  Oh, and the tiger.Now before you think this is one of those can't-we-all-just-get-along Disney movies - after all it is rated PG - forget about it.  One of the points driven home in the film is that these are animals and in fact, they do what animals do.  You get the picture.  Pi, realizing he isn't dealing with dogs and cats, uses the human brain and creates a makeshift raft which is tethered to the boat.  At certain times he is able to return to the boat for supplies and to check on the surviving tiger.Their confrontations are certainly the meat of the film, but that really isn't enough.  I saw this in 3-D and it is certainly the best use of the technology since "Avatar."  Directed by Ang Lee, the use is never in-your-face trickery, but is created on film as a new, dare I say art form?  While this film may not be life changing, it is beautifully made, creative and wondrous.  There are enough questions to keep the mind busy for days to come.  Lee and screenwriter David Magee masterfully adapt Yann Martel's novel.  And just when you are trying to soak it all it, an alternate version of the story gets the mind reeling.BLU RAY UPDATE (5-2-13):This Oscar winner, including director Ang Lee, begged to be seen again.  It ranked as my 10th favorite film from last year and would likely move up if I would have a do over.  This time I saw it in 2-D and it holds up nearly as well as it did on the big screen in 3-D.  While there is no understating the technical achievement of the film, it is also filled with wonderful emotional moments and big chunks of humor.For example, early in the story Pi relates how he became so interested in various religions.  He was a practicing Hindu as well as Christian and Muslim as a young teen.  Surprisingly this didn't seem to bother his parents.  In one exchange at the dinner table his father, Santosh (Adil Hussain), comments, "3 more religions and you'll spend your whole life on holiday." He then adds, "Think rationally."  The relationship Pi had with his father, including the respect for wild animals, is an important point in the story.The Blu ray transfer has an aspect ratio of 1.85:1, with a couple exceptions, and has a 1080p resolution.  As you might expect there are virtually no blips in the carryover that I could see.  This is a colorful movie and all the hues and shadings come across perfectly.  The film was digitally shot and is crystal clear.  Chapped lips and sunburned tiger nose are easily seen.  There is a couple format changes to note.  In one scene with the flying fish, the aspect ratio changes to a wider 2.35:1.  In another, a shot from overhead as a whale glides by the boat is shown in windowbox (1.33:1?).  These are brief scenes and while noticeable, they are not distracting.The audio is demo quality with a DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 track on full display.  There are scenes of quiet beauty (great musical score) and others of thunderous activity from all speakers.  An example is the violent ship sinking scene.  For some great sound effects, check out the tiger claws as he makes his way around and later into the boat.  This is a magnificent film paired with a superb transfer.  There are 3 documentaries involving the movie production as well as a photo gallery and some storyboards included in the extras.
summary: BLU RAY UPDATE:  Glorious movie making

reviewText: Though I personally loved this film I can see why some shy away. The movie does move slow in the beginning yes,but to me this movie is truly like a roller coaster in that you're going up this huge hill very slowly,but when you reach the peak and then plummet,your heart is in your throat the whole time.Life of Pi is truly one of those films that has it all. Heavy emotional drama,comedy, suspense,you name it you'll find a little bit of it in this film and its all done almost flawlessly.The character of Richard Parker is one of the best I think I've personally ever seen but what makes the Tiger companion so great isn't anything he does through the film but Pi's attachment to the animal.The 3D in this film is exceptional. I won't spoil anything,but the scene with the flying fish is probably the greatest 3D moment in any film to date. So if your a 3D buff,this movie is worth it for that one scene alone.I give the 3D 5 stars and the film itself 4.

reviewText: ----This review contains spoilers----I wanted to give this movie a 3.5/5 but after more consideration, decided to round-up instead of down.Having most of the movie centered around being adrift at sea was truly an achievement.  Most stories/movies could not have pulled that off.  There were a couple of scenes where I thought "not in a million years would that happen" but it wasn't so bad to detract from the movie.  That and it gives off that "Disney, creative imagination" vibe so you let it slide. The whole relationship he forms with the tiger is actually really well done and you feel like the tiger has a personality which lends weight to some of the scenes.Obviously the ending, when you find out everything may not be as it appears, is a solid twist, but in my opinion I feel like it kills the movie.  I understand the point the author wishes to convey (interpreting the story however you want) but this story was fun and magical and they could've went about the ending a little bit differently, even if they had to deviate from the book.  I know this would kill the spirit of the book/movie, and you have to take these things as they are, which is why I rounded-up and not down.  But I stand by this statement.  Being a realistic person, I know what the truth is, which means the movie/story/tiger is fake, and that sucks.  And yes: "reality does suck sometimes" but if I want a dose of this type of reality, I'll go watch Lincoln or Rust and Bone, not a magical, fun adventure like this.All-in-all though, a good movie worth a rental.  Some people may even put it in their collection.
summary: All in all a good movie.

reviewText: see it in 3D theaters instead because I felt the story was lacking. I don't know how the book is since I've never read it but the film didn't seem to have a story and characters that are very compelling. Ang Lee and his screenwriter needs to receive some credit in turning this tale into a feature movie, however. A story about a boy on a boat with a tiger where nothing much really happens except basic survival is difficult to shoot but Lee seemed to do as nice a job as it is possible given that challenge. Seeing the 3D version of the film may be the only redeeming feature of the movie. The 3d adds a depth not only to the images but to the story telling as well. Its use to convey depth in space is incorporated nicely by Lee into giving sense of loss and loneliness the boy feels in the ocean with all these non human animals in the boat and in vast the ocean. So while beautiful, original in its uses of CGI technology and poetic, these are the only reasons to see it as the story was lackluster and the characters also a little dull.

reviewText: If you want to watch a good survival movie, tryCast Awaywith Tom Hanks. Even with no animals, just a volleyball named Wilson, it was a more captivating movie than this one. Although I understand this movie is more about metaphysical questions, it just didn't work as an adventure-at-sea movie for me. It was long -- I could multitask, walk away, come back and pick up where I left off. And the ending entirely ruined it for me. When the investigators come to question Pi about the shipwreck, he tells two stories... and to him what matters is which is the better story, not which is the truth. I didn't like the inference that truth doesn't matter. If he weaves a fanciful tale in order for his psyche to survive, that's fine, and if he wants to let the fairy tale be the story, that's fine. But if there's another story about the shipwreck, and it is the true story (as true as something in fiction can be), gruesome though it was, that would be the story I'd prefer to hear, and I don't need a fairy tale to go alongside it.

reviewText: The Short: A visual marvel. A human triumph. A test of faith. Finding God. An incredible story. Life of Pi is this and many other things, sweeping the viewer away into a mesmerizing place that blurs the lines between dream and what is real.Ang Lee directs the previously thought un-filmable book to the big screen, Life of Pi. How it comes to life is breathtaking; an ingeniously woven tapestry of incredible visual elements and powerfully adept storytelling, all to the affect of discovering the greater meaning of being alive in a situation you would rather die in.It's an art movie that many audiences will love simply because of the gorgeous visuals, memorable character(s), and incredible spectacle. But for those looking for a deeper, meaty, and memorable movie going experience Life of Pi has you covered. No other movie nominated for best picture at the 2013 Oscars has perplexed me, moved me, made me reflect and think, and swept me away within its lush, visual imagery and unique storytelling. It's a film chock full of metaphor, visual imagery, and raw emotion. But this isn't a discussion of the film's many layers of religious undertones and imagery, but a review. I'll keep it that way!First off is director Ang Lee's incredible talent on display (for which he won Best Director - 2013). I have yet to read Life of Pi but from what I've heard from friends and book junkies is that Life of Pi is an incredibly complex, almost muddy in direction, novel which many considered un-filmable. What becomes of this epic tale of survival is a clean and expertly directed film, with all of its themes and underlying tones hidden within the visual landscape and story. It's not a force-fed experience, but rather one where you must process the vast array of information and make your own judgment on some of its less touched-on ideas. Whatever creative process Mr. Lee went through to bring this incredibly complex adventure to life is beyond me, and that's a true testament of the genius on display.You can't talk about Life of Pi without discussing the incredible visuals. Winning both Best Cinematography (2013) and Best Special Effects (2013) at the 2013 Academy Awards, I had high expectations going into Life of Pi. The film starts off, simply put, like any other PG-rated family film. I was nervous that it was going to be a bust. Where the film takes the viewer is someplace completely unique and unexpected. Without spoiling some of the finer moments, Life of Pi has visual panache to spare. There are some incredible moments that are rendered and recreated with such life-like detail that getting lost in Pi's tale is tremendously easy. Its visuals dazzle, but don't distract its storytelling, unlike other films (namely Avatar, which is a visual marvel but hardly a groundbreaking example of storytelling). One of the main strengths in Life of Pi is Richard Parker, the Bengal tiger that accompanies Pi during his quest. Little did I know that that 90 percent of his screen-time is completely computer animated. And it's not just that, but the rest of the film; the water effects, the tumbling ship, various animals; all of it is incredible. It maintains a perfect balance of realism and a dream-like quality. Some of the scenes are also shot with incredible vision and beauty. It's simply the most beautiful cinematography of any film last year (other than the Hobbit). I have nothing but praise for Life of Pi's cinematographer and special effects team.But no story is worth being told without great characters and actors to tell them. Life of Pi's Suraj Sharma (Pi) is absolutely fantastic. Emotional, powerful, and sincere; he is one seriously talented actor for never having been in a role before...ever. While the beginning of the film features a quick romance between Pi and Gita, featuring its fair share of awkward exchanges, its nothing annoying. Pi and his incredible story is what you see 90 percent of the time. It's his story of finding faith in the darkest of times, discovering courage where none should be present, and having the will to continue to live. The rest of the supporting cast does just fine in their various roles, aiding along the telling of a most grandiose adventure.Everything else is spectacular as well. The original score (also winning the Oscar for Best Score - 2013) fits the pages of Pi's story like clockwork. From the moving "Pi's Lullaby" to the gorgeous and ethereal "First Night, First Day", the original score never distracts but rather augments the experience, creating some of the most beautiful audio-visual-scapes in any film from recent memory. Sound editing is particularly fantastic. Crashing waves, minute sound effects; it's all done particularly well, especially in its transition to home video (aside from a couple of weird boom adjustments made mid scene that distract the acute ear). And boy, I can only imagine the splendor of the 3D this film had to offer but I, regretfully, was not able to see it in theaters, only on Blu-Ray. The one issue I had with the visual presentation was this, also noticed by Blu-Ray.com: "There are two spots in the film where the aspect ratio changes suddenly from the normal 1.85:1. During the "flying fish" sequence that was used as a teaser for the movie, the top and bottom close in to 2.35:1, and there's a single overhead shot of a whale passing beneath the lifeboat that inexplicably squeezes in to a window-boxed 1.33:1. I'm not sure what the rationale or workflow was here, so I can't really comment on it, but don't be alarmed by the out-of-nowhere framing changes." In layman's terms, the film goes from a whole-screen experience to having the black bars on the top and bottom and sides during two scenes, which is fairly distracting.Where Pi finishes his journey is up to you to discover and interpret. Where it stands for me, personally, is my favorite film of 2012. Visually spectacular, incredibly engaging, intricately told, and masterfully directed, Life of Pi was a massive gamble that pays off in more ways than one. It's an absolute classic.5/5 - Spectacular, Sensational; insert your own positive descriptor here and go see this movie!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Life of Pi takes you on the amazing adventure. A young castaway is stranded on a life boat with a Bengal Tiger. The film starts out in  India where you learn a little bit about Pi's family and his quest for spirituality. I loved how he followed a variety of religions, embracing their similarities instead of focusing on their differences. This strong faith is what helped him to handle the trials that followed. His father decides his family must leave India behind, and they take the entire menagerie from their zoo along with them. When the boat sinks, Pi finds himself on an ark of sorts with a few captive animals. Instead of letting being stranded with a carnivore destroy him, the tiger gives him a reason outside of himself to keep fighting, even though he is out on the water for over two hundreds days. Even when the story has ended, you're still left with questions that may never be answered. Was Pi really on the boat with animals or was it metaphor for something much more traumatic? Either way, Life of Pi is a film that confirms the power of faith and reminds us that we all have the strength inside of us to overcome even the most impossible situations.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I never read the book and didn't want to watch the movie, but saw it at a friend's house. Even though I didn't see it on the large screen or in 3D, it was mesmerizing. At first I was comfortably seated on a sofa, but midway through the film I found myself hunched forward, literally on the edge of my seat. By the end of the movie I was crying. That's how gripping the cinematography and special effects were, and to a certain extent the story itself. Although some people dislike the alternate ending, I found it wonderful. There are flaws, but the overall experience overcomes them. For example, in the first third of the tale, there is a fair amount of humor. The humor seems oddly out of place in the story as a whole and is soon dispensed with, never to return. There are some anomalies which are not explored, such as an instance where a goat on one side of a barred doorway is apparently taken through to the other side by a tiger. The tiger is a wonderful character and so realistically done that I thought a live animal was being used for much of the film until I learned otherwise. He has a name, Richard Parker, which seems to be an allusion to an actual person, but I don't want to spoil anything by explaining the reference. All the actors are quite good and manage to make you care for them, so when tragedy strikes, it really hits home. Apart from being trapped on a raft in the Pacific, water is a recurring theme, right down to Pi's real name...his full name is that of a French public swimming pool. The idea of rebirth is linked to that, and Pi's growth from introspective teen to self-sufficient man is a part of it. This is a dazzling and enchanting movie, and well worth watching.
summary: The special effects are greater than the flaws

reviewText: There are some subtitled parts in this movie, but these sections are brief and not a lot to read, so there shouldn't be too much groaning from those people who hate to have to read subtitles - hopefully knowing this going in will help you not mind so much.I watched this on my pc via Amazon instant video (not in blu-ray, 3D or even HD) - and I have to say the cinematography is really beautiful!  It is an interesting story - how could someone have thought this up, could this have really happened or is it all someone's imagination?  (It seems it was imagination.)The movie IS interesting, but as you might guess it would HAVE to be from the type of story it is, it sometimes feels long.  It does make you THINK now and then and so it stays with you, in your thoughts for a good time after the movie has ended.The different actors used to portray "PI" in various stages/ages of his life do not seem to look enough like each other to escape notice - but it's ok.  It doesn't seem to hurt the movie at all, just pointing out that we noticed so you probably will too.When PI is finally rescued, he is questioned about the loss of the ship (insurance, you know) - and they don't like his story (which you just watched, with the tiger and all) and so they ask him to come up with a more believable story.  When he relates the more believable version, he gets emotional and so you are left to wonder which is really true - and he asks which you prefer to be true.  Then the person PI is telling all this to notes correlation of the characters in each version, and I had to then replay the 2nd "believable" version for the insurance people to see that comparison for myself, so I was really glad I saw this on video and not live at the movies where I wouldn't have been able to do that.  ... it is an interesting little twist to the tale I think.It's a very CLEAN movie so good for the family (though kids have to deal with the subject of how vicious animals can be - which is a good lesson, but you want to be aware of that before a very young child sees this, so you're prepared), and PI is just a likable character - which is a MUST for a successful movie).I don't know if this is a movie I'd want to watch over and over - but it was one I did enjoy watching, and so I would recommend it to most viewers. (Some great special effects for the storms too!)

reviewText: When I saw this movie out at the theaters and read the synopsis I didn't want to even bother. Determined to live this boy fights the elements and finds the inner strength that we all possess. A great film for the entire family(though I was a little upset with the Zebra and Arangatang scene). Just goes to show, never judge a book by its cover. This movie is an amazing story and very entertaining!

reviewText: One might watch the trailer and groan at the prospect of another "The Black Stallion," but I have good news: this is not the same. Yes, both involve a ship sinking with one human survivor, and both have the survivor interact with animals while waiting for rescue. There is a key difference, though, that expands drastically with the final minutes of the film. In "The Black Stallion," the animal is a horse, something humans communicate with around the world. In Life of Pi, the tiger gives us something completely different. A natural enemy, very willing to devour. I'll get to the important meaning later.As is evident from the dramatic trailer, the cinematography is overwhelmingly beautiful. In all honesty, you don't see the half of it in the trailer. While at first, it didn't seem likely to work in 3D, I've put that view aside. It's the best live-action 3D I've ever seen! One of the best scenes (for the full emotional effect), is seeing the ship go down as if you were right there. In fact, more than one scene were so effective in this way that I was physically breathless. A few times during the film, Pi encounters rough storms, and this is where another beauty comes through. The camera captures the movement of Pi and his boat so well, it boggles me. While other movies have moved from cut to cut in moments, giving the impression of a storm, these cuts last much longer and show a lot more. It's as if filmed on location, with no misguiding.Something you should know before you watch is that Life of Pi breaks into the topic of religion quite a bit at the beginning. Pi follows several religions. First, Hindu, then Catholicism, and Muslim, all at once. After the incident, it doesn't come up much, apart from a few overtones, but it's important to be aware going in.This is a film for slightly older audiences (13+) for the reasons of the ship's intense sinking, and for the complicated concepts of the film.To warn you, this last paragraph is a bit *SPOILER* oriented. Near the end of the movie, Pi tells another story, showing what the tiger represents. Suffice it to say that there is more meaning to this than surviving on an island with a horse and winning a race with him later on. I won't spoil any more, though.In conclusion, this is a beautiful movie about survival and perseverance, in the midst of harsh, beautiful nature.

reviewText: Wow, what a pleasant surprise....even though i read the book i was still blown away by this totally unique & enthralling film.This movie is moved by underlying currents of deep meaning that effectively pulled me in slowly but surely .... into a thought provoking heartfelt experience that left me glowing with new appreciation for life & all i share the journey with.One reason i was able to be pulled so deeply into this was the acting....top notch, & the visuals are stunning... also....the actors are all fresh faces to me....so it bumped up the believability factor as there were no memories of past performances attached to the faces to pop up & interrupt the experience.Seriously, the actor who plays the young Pi deserves an Academy award for this one.... or at least a standing ovation....HE made it believable....not the special effects.Congratulations is in order for all involved in this masterpiece of a movie.I put off seeing this because i figured since i had read the book...i would be encumbered by the "been there done that" syndrome....but strangely enough that was not the case at all even though it seemed to follow the books story line pretty closely.I wont go into details, im sure there are plenty of reviews that are giving plot specifics...so i will wrap up the review by saying that this is one of the few movies that I KNOW i will be watching again soon...as there is just too much to take in, in just one viewing.

reviewText: "Life of Pi" is another stunning example of Lee's artistry, one that defies any formulaic account of how the magic of life in all its delicate detail is brought to screen. Lee's sensibility is primed to make the best of the literary adaptation of the Booker Prize winning novel by Yan Martel. The trials following "Pi" Patel the youngest member of the Patel Family, zookeepers who have resolved to move from their native Pondicherry, in India, to Canada, is brought to screen with subtlety at so many levels that one cannot help but marvel at Lee's sense for storytelling, his eye for talent, and for his ability to bring to life the many emotional registers of this story of a resilient father lost to a son, and a son who in turn manages to bring that father's life lessons to bear on his quest to accomplish what is truly grand in life. Pi's rage to find a response to the final questions he has on God, the meaning of life, and the vast array of philosophies that merges and emerges growing up in the heart of the great tropics - India - is the grandest example of a cinematic "trip" we have had all year.The scenes with "Pi" telling his story in flashback, of his quest for religious unity in a world where Gods and Dieties abound and haunt his imagination, his conversations with books late into the night, along with altercations and loving interludes with his close and inseparable family is contrasted with the uncompromising self-reliant individualism that Pi is subjected to in that fateful journey across the seas. The long migration to Canada initially seems like a fool's quest but the deeper emotional notes in Pi's odyssey across the seas has an empowering tragic sense of life that has no equal this year at the movies.Ang Lee stretches his own range of interests in his quest for a deeper emotional connection with religious themes in Martel's novels. Pi's lone quest in a raft, struggling to come to terms with his demons, in the open sea, also opens up a range of interpretations. Depending on your interpretive mood and fancy, Pi's altercations with a Tiger, Orangutan, and Zebra, could be taken as real or figurative/hallucinatory encounters.The sheer beauty and detail of the digital imagery that unfolds on screen, the breathtaking vision of young Pi lost in the ocean is, in and of itself, only spectacle. But these visuals, become a beautiful, even consoling, vision of a human being absorbed in his infinite struggles and longings. The brilliant decorative pieces on the cinematic canvas become vast signifiers of life's deepest meanings. And none of this gets ponderous, or pretentious. This is a tale told simply, furiously, of Pi's resolve, of his sadness, love, loss, and protests. Pi's scream in a crucial hallucinatory moment, when he is numbed by thirst, hunger, and exhaustion, and face to face with his father, his mother, his brother, lying deep in the ocean, in a cry of protest, is the best single scene at the movies this year. His protest transcends the infinite stretches of the skies and the ocean above and below him.  Lee's attention to Pi's anguish, this moral epicenter of this grand visual spectacle, is a moment on screen that reminded me, again, of the aesthetic power of cinema. Great directors do this constantly and Ang Lee manages to bring these moments to the screen this year more than any other film I have seen. A young man striving to remain true to his calling, as a son, an orphan, and finally a representative human being striving beyond his native strength, is a great moment of cinema, where tragedy and triumph meet without separation.Lee shows how he has developed mastery over stories that have incredible reserves of human emotion when it is handled with deftness. Lee knows when to let the narrative drift in the high seas of this drama and he also knows when to build and unleash those transcendent moments in his careful staging of the characters and scenes, in some truly unforgettable flights of cinematic artistry. This is an old fashioned story, in turns allegorical and deeply human, that relies on Lee's control, his unerring sense of timing and quiet artistry, his impeccable awareness of how to control the tension in the drama during its ebbs and flows.This story of Pi Patel and his family is perhaps Ang Lee's best film since "Sense and Sensibility" and his underestimated Hulk (2003) and is also my pick for the best movie of the year.Lee is at the peak of his powers, doing what he does best, in his third decade as a major director, with his delicate perceptive powers coming into its own in its fullest expression. "Life of Pi" is literary material with a moral theme that can turn stiff, dull, and pretentious in less able directorial hands. But Ang Lee manages to keep his explorations of the triumph and tragedy of life on screen well within the bounds of taste to make Pi's unraveling tragic story a redeeming one. What is on display here is the simple miracle of family life, its redeeming power, despite the tensions and tragedies that abound on the surface.

reviewText: This film has convinced me that movie critics are in collusion with film makers to keep the industry profitable. Life of Pi is highly overrated.A writer interviews the syncretistic main character who has a fascinating life story to tell. However, beyond that, there seems to be no point to this film. Life of Pi teases the viewer with the promise of a profound spiritual insight, but that never happens.Oddly, the talented actor Gérard Depardieu cast as a surly chef on the doomed freighter and appears for less than 30 seconds in the film. Looks like Depardieu’s best work ended up on the proverbial cutting room floor.Cinematographically, this is a beautiful film. I can’t argue with that.Unfortunately the digital animations of the zoo animals were not quite realistic enough for me.My recommendation is: don’t waste your money. If you do, mute the TV until the last 5 minutes, which is the only part worth watching.

reviewText: "Life of Pi" (2012 release; 126 min.) brings the story of an Indian boy, named Piscine Patel, nicknamed Pi, as he grows up with his family on a zoo in India. Because of falling fortunes, Pi's dad decides to move the family to Canada, taking the animals of the zoo with them on their cross-Pacific Ocean journey with the idea to sell the animals upon arrival. Then disaster strikes as the ship meets a mega-storm and sinks. Pi manages to get on a life-saver boat, only to find that several animals made it onto the boat as well, a hyena, a zebra, an orangutan and a bengal tiger. To tell you more of what happens after that would ruin your viewing experience, you'll just have to find out and experience it for yourself.Several comments: the movie truly kicks into gear about 30 min. into it when the storm hits the ship transporting the family and the animals, with astounding visuals. The next hour of the movie finds Pi adrift on the Pacific Ocean with the several animals that somehow got onto the life-boat. At that point it reminded me of the Tom Hanks movie "Castaway" some years ago, albeit with one big exception: the visuals of the movie, in particularly when watching it in 3D as I did in the theatre today, are simply amazing. Eye-candy pure and simple. These days, 3D movies are rarely worth the bother, but this one is the beautiful exception, perhaps the best use of 3D since "Avatar".A shout-out to Suraj Sharma as the 16 yr. old Pi, who brings an outstanding performance, in particular since the many scenes he does with the bengal tiger, who is entirely CGI (although amazingly and incredibly looking real life). Also a special note to also to Mychael Danna who scored the beautiful soundtrack for the movie (it is available on CD). In all, I thorougly enjoyed this movie from start to finish. I was amazed how quickly it rolled by. "Life of Pi" is one of those movies that needs to be seen on the big screen, and in 3D at that. "Life of Pi" is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
summary: 4.5 stars... Needs to be seen on the big screen in 3D

reviewText: We watched this on our family movie night with our daughters ages 10 and 13, without having read any reviews or having any idea of what the movie is about.  Our 10 year old thought it was scary, but huddled close to her dad and made it through the whole thing.  The movie and plot is quite engaging; it's hard to know what is "real" and what is imagined -- until the end.  It was too metaphorical for our kids to understand -- and that is probably a good thing, given what the main character had to do to survive.  It was pretty thought-provoking -- after-the-fact -- for the adults who watched.  Our kids watched the whole thing, but they really didn't enjoy it very much.
summary: Weren't sure what to expect, but it wasn't what we expected

reviewText: The most amazing 3D quality movie that shows underwater footage and sea life. Life of Pi is base on a popular book by Yann Martel's novel that sold over 7 million copies. It's about a boy name Piscine Patel known as Pi (Suraj Sharma). He has a good life growing up in his father's zoo in Pondicherry, a French colony. Due to hard times, they have to close down the zoo and move some of the animals to Canada with them. The move to Canada is in a big Japanese cargo ship and all the animals are at the bottom of the ship.A big storm hits the ship and sinks it. The survivors are Pi, a tiger (Richard Parker), zebra, hyena, orangutan and a rat. They are all in a small life boat from the cargo ship. After several days, the only two survivors are Pi and Richard Parker. They were afraid of each other but need each other to survive.There are so many scenes with great cinema-photography. The most memorable ones are the underwater footage and the sinking of the cargo ship is so real and clear. The 3D brings out the glowing of the jelly fish and the blue wale vividly. Special effects of the tiger is the best part. It seems so real, I thought that the tiger is actually in the boat with Pi. The part I did not like is when the animals were fighting each other. It's too hard to watch the survival of the fittest.The acting in this movie is so great. Suraj show a lot of emotions with his eyes and he stays in character and the audience can feel his emotions. It's so amazing to see his weight loss as the days go by at sea. My favorite character is Richard Parker. He helps Pi survive the shipwreck and at times he seems more human than creature. The lesson in this movie is anything is possible. Pi survives over seven months in the Pacific Ocean with just faith and Richard Parker.I rank this movie 4 out of 5 stars. I give this age range 8 and up. Cheyenne N, KIDS FIRST! Film Critic.This is truly an amazing story, with a great adventure that is hard to believe. Pi, (Suraj Sharma) an Indian boy, is on a ship with his family who is moving to Canada. One night there is a terrible storm that sinks the ship and only Pi, a Hyena, Zebra, Orangutan and a Bengal Tiger whose name is Richard Parker survive. They are all in one of the small life boats trying to stay alive. After a while it only becomes Pi and Richard Parker who are adrift in the Pacific Ocean. Pi is now trying to survive, but is in fear of Richard Parker.Based on the best-selling novel by Yann Martel, this adventure is created in 3D and is one of my new favorites. The visual effects are amazing and capture the marine life really well with all its beautiful colors. I like the way this film is set up like someone is telling it as a story, this really keeps my attention. One of my favorite scenes is when a big whale comes out of the ocean; it is so big and pretty to see. It is incredible. I also like the way we learn how the Tiger is named Richard Parker. It is somewhat funny and unusual.I would love to know How Director, Ang Lee, directs all the animals in this film, it is truly amazing how they act. David Magee, (Screenplay writer) is doing a remarkable job on transforming a great novel into an amazing script. Other casts in Life of Pi include Vibish Sivakumar (Ravi Patel) and Rafe Spall (The Writer).A big message I found is to never lose hope no matter where you are in life. Pi is in the middle of the ocean for many many days with a big storm, and a Tiger, but through it all he never loses hope to be rescued. I recommend this film for ages 8 to adults. Younger ages may be a little frightened when they see some of the animal scenes, but other than that, this is a must see. You can enjoy it with your family and friends. I give Life of Pi 5 out of 5 stars. I love the message and the visual effects. This is a great story of hope and determination. Believe the unbelievable and see the amazing adventure in Life of Pi, it triumphs into theaters on November 21. by Brianna H, KIDS FIRST! Film Critic.
summary: Great Message. Fabulous Visual Effects. Incredible Story - A Must See

reviewText: The concept of this film is bizaare.Hardly inspired but certainly iconoclastic just for the sake of being so.And then submitting two possible interpretations at the very end - what does that add?It begins with an odd premise in the first place - a vegetarian family in India that runs a private zoo full of carnivorous animals who moves it to Canada on a ship - well it's a new first at least.It's implausible from the beginning but succeeds thereafter as an involving fantasy with appealing visuals.The tacked on alternative ending serves little purpose but I guess does serve to bring it all down to reality in a certain way.An oddity is this film's obsession with vegetarianism vs. meat eating.From the Buddhist ship travellers assuring the Indian family that the gravy is ok for a vegetarian (even though it might have meat in it???) , to the father showing the son the violence of the tiger as it attacks a helpless young goat, to the implied gorging of the tiger on the orangutan, zebra and hyena, to the vegetarian family with carnivores to an island of more meerkats per sq. foot than ever seen before providing more flesh for the tiger.......see what I mean?The whole thing is nonsensical.  Or maybe it just requires more suspension of belief than the usual movie fantasy.Also I understand why he is called Pi, but what does that have to do with anything else in the story?Including his ability to memorize and calculate incredible numbers of digits for the value of pi?Even though there never was a moment when I thought "Gee why didn't I think of that" I give it 4 stars anyway for the wtf factor alone.
summary: Contrived and Not thought provoking but highly visual

reviewText: Ang Lee's film "Life of Pi" is a technological marvel, perfectly blending 3D and state of the art digital effects with a great adventure story which is also remarkably spiritual. It all comes together for a deeply moving motion picture experience.The Blu-ray is stellar as well. The film features some of the best usage of 3D since James Cameron's "Avatar" and Martin Scorsese's "Hugo". It's perfectly replicated on this 3-disc collector's edition. This set also includes a standard 2D version of the film which also looks amazing. Audio is fully immersive and perfectly replicates the film's sonic power.The extras are spread over the 2D and 3D Blu-ray discs. These include deleted scenes, a detailed hour-long "making of" documentary, and additional features which explore the film's Oscar-winning visual effects. Also included in this version is a DVD copy of the film and digital copies (iTunes & Ultraviolet). Overall, a great value and a great Blu-ray package!

reviewText: While the gorgeous cinematography of this movie alone makes it worth seeing, I wasn't impressed with it overall.  A man retells the events that he experienced as a boy during and after a shipwreck with zoo animals and his family.  The promise is made early on that this is a story that will "make you believe in God."  If this, indeed, is the purpose of the film, it failed miserably.  On that front, it was confusing at best.  I think it would be much more accurate to say, "This is a story that explains how some people view religion and ecumenicalism."  On the positive side, it does make the viewer think long after the show's over, but by the time I was done thinking, my analysis was that I didn't agree with the author.  Eh, it was probably worth seeing, but it's definitely not going to make my top 100 list.
summary: A nice film that just doesn't live up to the hype

reviewText: My immediate reaction after watching this film in 3D..."Stunning, absolutely stunning!" It is a great story, compelling and powerful: part survival story, part fantasy, part animal psychology...and all in glorious 3D visual artistry. It is also the story of faith; although the protagonist, Pi Patel's approach to God is an ambiguous one, in that he espouses the Hindu, Christian and Islamic faiths. At one point his father says, "following multiple faiths is no faith at all!"; and I would agree, but somehow Pi's simplicity of faith is believable. While the lion's (or Tiger's) share for the excellence of this film - my opinion - should go to Ang Lee, the performance by 17 year old Suraj Sharma, in his film debut, as Pi Patel, should not be overlooked. It is in many ways a masterful performance, not often attained by experienced actors twice or three times his age. The CGI/special effects, which like the cast, is international in scope, is also a wonder to behold...even if you do not care for the story, the visuals make the movie worth watching. And the story...look for a twist at the end that will likely surprise you.
summary: Very few castaways can claim to have survived so long, and none in the company of an adult Bengal tiger."

reviewText: This is the most artistic use of 3D I have seen on Blu-ray to date.Watching the BD inspired me to read the book by Yann Martel. The film follows the book religiously. (No pun intended). Nothing of importance is left out. The visuals of the movie matched the narrative of the book as I read. Purists will be pleased.The DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 (48kHz, 24-bit) audio is superb.Ang Lee richly deserved the Best Director Award he received at the Oscars for this masterpiece. This is reference audio and video.The use of CGI in this film is fantastic. Every scene you see where the tiger is alone in the frame is a real tiger. I challenge you to tell the difference between the real and the CGI tiger.A bit about the story. This is not a religious movie per se. It is the portrayal of a boy who finds himself in a horrendous situation, fraught with peril. He must draw on all he has learned and experienced in his young life to cope with the reality of the moment. It is a testament to the human will to survive against all odds. An uplifting experience.This should not be missed.

reviewText: Let me start off by saying the 4 stars are for the movie itself.The film is quite interesting and very well developed. I wasn't crazy about some of the CGI animals, but overall it was pulled off rather well. I've read other reviews asking why he kept doing a certain thing and it makes me think that maybe people didn't fully understand the movie. Others complained that it was slow, but the pacing seemed fine for this type of film. It's not supposed to be a big action movie so I can't imagine anyone wanting to speed up the story telling. In a lot of ways, it made me think of Ernest Hemingway's book The Old Man and The Sea. It felt very much like that in so many ways, but Pi puts in a little more craziness. Overall, I thought the film was very good and worth the rental fee.Now, as far as the blu ray disc...it doesn't seem to work in all players. I actually rented the Blu Ray disc and it would not play in my blu ray player. I did the usually stuff like updating the firmware to the latest update. Still, no go. I tried playing it in my computer which has a blu ray player. Nothing. I updated the blu ray software on my comp and still nothing. I did some research and some people have stated that because of a very new type of menu on the blu ray not all players will be able to play it, even with all available updates. It seems that some companies have not updated their software / firmware to make the blu ray work, but I am sure it will be fixed very soon. I had the same problem with the blu ray version of Skyfall. Hopefully, this issue can be worked out as I prefer the clarity of a blu ray over a dvd.4.2 / 5
summary: A Fine Movie, but A Problem Blu Ray

reviewText: This movie excels in so many ways, but special mention should be given to the cinematography, direction and acting.  Visually, this is pure eye candy.From the standpoint of direction, with one small exception, it is flawless.  That flaw is the scene in the family's cabin while the ship is in very heavy seas.  Pi is leaning over the side of his bunk, arm hanging down, but there is no suggestion of motion.  What I can't decide is if this was intentionally done to make the severity of the storm a form of shock and awe, or simply, an omission.The acting, especially all the age variations of Pi, was spot on.  everyone performed well.The CGI in this film was outstanding.  You would be hard pressed to tell that wasn't a real tiger.  The 3-D was good throughout, with no obvious attempts to get oohs and ahs.The storyline, for reasons that become apparent has some inconsistencies, but that is as it should be.  A well told tale.

reviewText: Ang Lee's adaptation of the strangely beloved novel is, to my recollection (it's been a few years since I read the book) quite faithful to both the events and the spirit of the novel.  And thus, it has many of the same successes and failures of the source material.Pi is a young man, living in India with his family.  They run a zoo there, and Pi learns to love animals.  He's also a boy full of curiosity, and as he becomes acquainted with Hindu, Catholic & Jewish beliefs and traditions, he embraces a hodge-podge of ideas.  He selects what sounds good to him, or what is most helpful to him in coming to understand the world around him...both what he sees and what can't be seen.Eventually, the family is forced by political upheavals to move the entire zoo enterprise to Canada.  But on the sea voyage across the Pacific, a terrible storm hits and the ship sinks.  Pi finds a lifeboat, but so do several zoo animals, including, most importantly, the Bengal Tiger named Richard Parker.  The bulk of the movie deals with Pi and Parker's LOOOONG sea voyage and how they survive a harsh environment, the wondrous things they see and the relationship they establish.Lee has filmed this saga in 3D, and I recommend you see the film this way if you can.  The 3D is some of the most sparkling and dazzling since AVATAR.  While it's clear much of the film must be CGI, the CGI rarely shows.  In fact, it is nearly impossible to believe that the tiger wasn't flesh & blood much of the time.  It is rendered dazzlingly.  In fact, the whole movie sparkles in a way that creates a heightened reality (or, puts a touch of fantasy onto reality).  There's no question in my mind that from a technical perspective, LIFE OF PI is one of the best this year.The story itself is undeniably gripping.  I liked that no sentimental relationship is developed between Pi and the tiger.  This animal is a killer.  It is wild and dangerous.  The two create an understanding, but there is never mutual affection.  It is not a story of anthropomorphism.  There are many utterly gripping scenes (the storm is particularly effective), a fair number of humorous moments and some scenes that are simply gorgeous to look at.  Even though the pace is somewhat deliberate at times, I was never bored.But, as with the book, PI wants to be profound.  The narrator of the film (I won't say more about who that is) tells a listener, "you will believe in God" after hearing the story.  I not see how this story could make someone believe in God.  The ending essentially attempts to be a validation of the young Pi's early ideas about embracing what you want from various religions rather than needing to follows all the dictates of just one belief system.  While one could debate the merits of this argument (and the other argument the end of the film posits, which I won't hint at for fear of spoiling things)...there is NO emotional heft to them within the LIFE OF PI.  This was the huge failing of the book, which told such a splendid story, only to diffuse it all with poppycock pop spiritualism.  Lee, rightfully so, I suppose, has not changed this...but his film also collapses under the mundane nature of this films revelations.  (PI author Yann Martel's follow-up novel BEATRICE AND VIRGIL suffers the same bloated sense of self-importance, but is also unpleasant to read).I know others find the insights of LIFE OF PI to be nearly miraculous.  I'm sorry, I just don't see it.  To me, this story has become one of those things we now teach in schools (my daughter had to read it in high school) because it SEEMS as though it has great literary import.  The fact is, it is 97% wonderful, but 3% utter navel-gazing.  That 3% can't completely destroy what has become before, but it sure left a bad taste in my mouth, both in book or cinematic form.  By all means, you should see it.  Ang Lee has done some of his best work here.  But take it for what it is, and not for what it pretends to be.
summary: So many GREAT elements, but it's pretensions nearly undo it all.

reviewText: Life of Pi was one of the best books I've read in a while, I loved it. Often a movie is disappointing when compared to the book but I think they did an excellent job of capturing the essence of the book. There were a few minor changes, which my wife quibbled about but all in all a wonderful job of capturing a magical story. The 3D was nicely done.The story itself is about an Indian boy who has a great interest in religion (Hindu, Christian, and Muslim) whose family owns a zoo in India. His family leaves India for Canada, taking the animals with (sold to zoos in Canada). The ship sinks in the Pacific and only Pi, a bengal tiger (Richard Parker), an orangatang (Orange Juice), a zebra with a broken leg and a hyena make it into the lifeboat.
summary: A nice representation of a book I love

reviewText: Life of Pi(released Sept/12)stars,among others,Suraj Sharma as Pi,age 16,Irrfan Khan as Pi,adult,Tabu as Gita Patel,Pi's mother,Adil Hussain as Santosh Patel,Pi's father and Gérard Depardieu as the Cook.This is a stunningly visual treat which keeps you mesmerized through a good part of the film.The animals that one sees through a good part of the film,are mostly CGI creations.And it is not hard to tell that they are just that,but the film doesn't linger too long on them as to undo your suspension of disbelief altogether.Lee just keeps pushing the story along.And that story opens as a reporter in Montreal is interviewing an Indian man who starts to relate a rather bizarre tale;one that will have you "believing in God".The man relates as to how he got his name of Pi,as in the mathematical symbol.It seems an uncle liked a swimming area in Paris called the Piscine Molitor,and he became Pi for short.One day the father sees the writing on the wall and he decides to move his family to Canada;Winnipeg specifically.The father and the family run a zoo.They sell what animals they can and take the rest.Part way through the voyage,just past Indonesia,a fierce storm comes up and the ship sinks,taking with it Pi's entire family.In a lifeboat hanging from the davit,there is the ships cook,into which is thrown Pi.Suddenly a Zebra loose from below decks,jumps from a storey up and onto the boat,breaking both its legs and sending the cook overboard and the boat into the water.Pi ends up in the water more than once but witnesses from under it the ships last breath as it sinks beneath the waves like a surreal lighted leviathan.Pi makes it back into the boat.Next morning things start to move.A hyena suddenly appears from under the boat awning cover and starts to harass Pi and the Zebra.Suddenly an orangutang joins this motley crew.It isn't long before the hyena gets its sea legs and it starts to attack and kills the zebra.Time passes and it goes after and kills the orangutang.Just as it is about to attack Pi a tiger comes out from under the awning and kills the hyena.From this moment on Pi must learn not only to survive but survive without getting eaten by the tiger.For the first part of their journey Pi builds himself a makeshift raft on which to live,keeping a rope attached from the boat to his raft.Eventually,after many travails,and at the end of his rope,Pi comes on board and teaches the tiger how to behave when told.It surprisingly works and the two get on relatively well.They come upon a floating island whose inhabitants are mostly meerkats.It has fresh water ponds in which to drink and the tiger has plenty of food(meerkats).As Pi lay asleep in the night the meerkats take to the tress and the tiger goes back to the boat.The why becomes plainly clear when at night the ponds become acidic and kill everything that are in or may fall into them.Pi and the tiger leave the island the next day.They eventually wash up on shore in Mexico and are rescued.Shortly thereafter reps from the Japanese shipping company come a calling to Pi asking questions about the reasons behind the sinking and his story of survival.Pi relates the tiger story to them and when they ask for the truth he relates another story of he being stranded with his mother,a sailor and the cook.The sailor was injured and the cook killed the sailor.When a struggle occurs later his mother pushes Pi to safety as she gets stabbed to death.Pi later returns and kills the cook and drifts alone at sea until he reaches Mexico.In the present the reporter looks at the actual shipping report and it seems the reps chose the tiger story over the other.When asked by a now grown up Pi which one he preferred,he replies the tiger story also.The film ends as Pi introduces the reporter to his two children and his wife.After all we have seen and experienced Lee decides to give us a nice twist of an ending.Which story would we have preferred to see?.....the tiger story of course,and that is what we got.As the film begins one wonders where it is going as it visually describes Pi's childhood,which has its funny and serious moments.But the movie really starts to take off at about 30 minutes into the film when the ship begins to founder and sinks.One really feels like you are right there with Pi as he experiences the monumental loss of not only his family,but his way of life,all his belongings and the ship that would take him to a new life.With just his wits,some common sense,the teachings of his family and his religious beliefs,he must somehow survive and endure an indescribably tough,but at the same time,beautifully rich life trial.Along the way we are treated to a myriad of visually stunning moments such as the appearance of bio luminescent fish and a whale who breaches as it comes up to feed on same,the meerkats on the island,the sinking of the ship and so many more.And,if you haven't guessed,they are just that much more stunning because it may not have been real to begin with....right?Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r of 1:85:1.There is an"extra"category on this DVD but all it contains are trailers.Kind of a false advert if you ask me.All in all a treat for the visual senses.A simple story told with a straightforward touch but with a heck of a twist ending.The CGI animals are good but not fool proof,and Ang Lee steers his film with a deft touch never lingering too long on any one thing.It was nominated for 11 statues and won four.Well deserved.4 1/2 stars.Excellent but not perfect.

reviewText: Ang Lee's "Life of Pi" is a masterpiece with some of the most beautiful and unforgettable images ever displayed on film. Not only did it give me an experience of the wonder in being alive while moving me to tears, but its story also encompassed a human life from childhood to mature age while dealing with pain and guilt that are part of the human experience.Ang Lee isn't thought of as an Asian auteur in the class of Wong Kar-wai, Zhang Yimou or Lee Chang-dong. He's actually more of a commercial director than a personal artist, but what he does in transferring the "Life of Pi" from novel to screen is miraculous.  Perhaps no director has ever captured the beauty and fear of the power of life, and when you look deep into the eyes of the tiger "Richard Parker", you see what Marlowe saw in Kurtz's eyes in Conrad's "The Heart of Darkness": a power so vast it dwarfs you with an awareness of your mortality, showing you your insignificance beside the powers of all life.  What Ang Lee does here in this film will, I believe, remain his tour-de-force, and is a work of art I will come to many times in the future.The acting is wonderful, primarily Irrfan Khan, one of India's greatest actors who plays the adult Pi.  Khan provides an entire acting course just in the way he uses his face, displaying a smile in the film's climax that rivals the Mona Lisa's in its ambiguity.  You see the world of pain, guilt, joy and sadness in his delicate expression.The film is supremely spiritual in every frame, yet, if one is paying attention, it winds up as somewhat of a Trojan Horse in what it ultimate reveals about religion.  I'm trying hard not to provide a spoiler here, but there are five words spoken by the adult Pi at the end of the film that viewers seem to miss that spell it out.  But moving away from its theme, no film I have ever seen in my life comes close to "Life of Pi" in relating the sheer force of nature (making you experience the beauty and terror in the soul of a tiger) and the cosmic beauty of our world, both inner and outer.  Using 3-D more brilliantly (and essentially) than any film to date, this film burned into my mind incredible visual sights impossible to find anywhere else, showing me beauty I will remember the rest of my life.Highly recommended, and one that truly deserves to be seen in 3-D.
summary: A must-see masterpiece of the beauty of being alive

reviewText: ****1/2In an era in which CGI has made it possible to put virtually anything one could possibly imagine up on the screen, it has become harder and harder for a filmmaker to make an audience's collective jaw drop. But Ang Lee achieves just that with his adaptation of Yann Martel's "Life of Pi." This movie truly has what we, in modern parlance, like to refer to as "the wow factor," simply because it is unlike anything we've seen on screen before. "Life of Pi" is a surrealistic tale of survival about an Indian boy trapped on a lifeboat in the middle of the ocean with nothing but a ferocious Bengal tiger for a companion.The first thought we are struck with while watching "Life of Pi" is that this movie would have been impossible to make prior to the CGI revolution in filmmaking. With so many movies abusing that technology for sheer commercial ends, it's gratifying to see a film actually using it for thought-provoking and artistic purposes (see also "Gravity"). At times brutally harsh while at others gloriously lyrical, the movie combines the realistic with the fantastical, the rational with the spiritual - all to illustrate the many disparate and dichotomous elements that, working in glorious chaotic tandem, make up this vast expanse we call the universe.The first third of the film focuses on Pi's life before the shipwreck. Pi (short for Piscine, which as it shares a rather unfortunate homonym in English, causes Pi at a very early age to abbreviate it) is innately curious about not only the world around him but the world that lies beyond the physical. He is so fascinated with the spiritual, in fact, that he has adopted the tenets of each of the world`s major religions and made them his own. Pi lives with his stern, skeptical father (Adil Hussain), his more open-minded, sympathetic mother (Tabu) and his somewhat less curious older brother (who is played by three different actors in various stages of the story). One of the prime exhibits in the zoo owned by Pi's father is a Bengal tiger that, through a bureaucratic fluke, has been tagged with the name Richard Parker, a prosaic moniker hardly befitting the king of the jungle. When the father decides to sell the zoo, the family, along with the animals, board a Japanese freighter to begin a new life in Canada (the plan is to sell the animals once they get there). On the way, however, tragedy strikes when the ship sinks in a tremendous storm, sending all but Pi and Richard Parker to the bottom of the sea. "Life of Pi" is the story of their survival.Alternately awe-inspiring, heartbreaking and suspenseful, the screenplay by David Magee expands on the  "circle of life" metaphor to explore how each element of nature is interlocked with every other element, with each action prompting a reaction unto infinity. Though natural born "enemies," Pi and Richard Parker achieve a kind of symbiosis, ultimately forced to rely on one another for survival (RP for his physical needs, Pi for his spiritual), and in so doing, they achieve a harmony that puts them in sync with the rest of the universe. Yet, for all its pantheistic elements, the movie doesn't over-sentimentalize nature, doesn't shy away from showing us the unthinking brutality that is also a part of that universe, underlined by the fact that living creatures can survive only by feeding on other living creatures. It certainly never downplays the very real danger Pi is in at every moment from his feline companion. This cat may be animated, but he's no cartoon character.Never one to shy away from a challenge, Lee won a second Best Director Oscar for his work here, and someday the Academy might even see fit to bestow a Best Picture award on him as well (he was certainly robbed of that honor for "Brokeback Mountain"). As he has done many times before, Lee demonstrates a total command of the medium in "Life of Pi." There's a hallucinatory quality to much of the film, as Pi frequently experiences preternatural visions that transcend the confines of the material world and of rational thought, leading him to a oneness with God.Suraj Shama has been handed the challenge - one might almost call it the burden - of carrying large stretches of this film entirely on his own, with only a CGI effect to interact with. It is a challenge the gifted young actor is more than equipped to handle and he fulfills it beautifully.Though the movie throws the audience for a loop at the end, making us question the veracity of the tale the adult Pi (Irrfan Kahn) is relating to the writer (Rafe Spall) who hopes to chronicle the experience, no one can ever convince the true believer in all of us that this is anything other than a love story between a boy and a tiger. After all - thanks to the technical wizards who've made it all possible - we've seen it with our own eyes.

So much care, love, and thought went into filming Life of Pi.I have decided which story is true and will watch it again and again and be affected again and again.A great film.

reviewText: The movie is like a puddle that pretends to be a sea.The plot is simple, though it does not mean that simple plots go with bad movies. It's just a fact that the plot is not that sophisticated:The main character tells a writer a long story with a promise that after hearing it, the writer will believe in God. So the storyteller tells how he survived a disaster at sea, sailing in a boat with a Bengal tiger. At the end of the story the teller suddenly says that it was not true and tells an alternative, more scarier story of his survival without the tiger. Then the teller asks the writer which story he prefers. The writer chooses the first story, with the tiger. And the teller says that it goes with God. As simple as that.I'm surprised that the movie's budget was 150 mil. Where is the money? In 3D and visual effects? Do they call it movies nowadays? For me, a good movie is a well-told story, not a show of technical progress. I wanted to see a story of a spiritual odyssey, personal growth, how the main character loses or obtains his faith, how a boy becomes a man, but it was all so shallow that I feel cheated.Why should someone believe in God if he listens to the story? Why does the first story go with God and why can't the second story go with God? What's wrong with it? Does the author mean that believing in good sweet stories means to have faith? Is God just a palatable story that people choose to believe? Why does the truth must be something that one choose to believe in? Why does the boy start believing in 3 religions and finish at the same level? He does not change, does not growth, doesn't question his faith.Was he searching for God? He was but where is his journey? He is not an "enlightened" person but still the same nave young boy, a flat cartoon character all the time. He starts as a nave believer and ends up as a nave believer, no lapses, no temptations, and no spiritual growth. Did he "surrender" to God? So what? It does not make the story more intelligent or spiritual, or less cooked up and artificial.I do not want to choose neither story because I do not like them both. Neither story proves anything for me. To me, it's mainly a story about how a boy tamed a tiger sailing in one boat. The rest - so called "layers" and allegories are nonsense, attempts to add depth to look wise and philosophical but in fact, it's just a substitute of a true spiritual journey. It's an ersatz spirituality taught by an ersatz guru.A friend of mine asked me who I think Richard Parker (the tiger) was in fact? I have no idea. It's an open-ended question. There are no right or wrong answers, I guess. The answer that one believes is "true" - must be the true answer for the believer. It could be the tiger, it could be the boy (since he had known the tiger since the Zoo times), it could be God or personal relationships of God and the boy, it could be the boy's animal nature, it could be his relative, it could be the cook (why not?), it could be just a fruit of the boy's imagination, or Yann Martel (the author) himself, or it could meanall things together at the same or different time.There is a chance that none story is real, so it's hard to explore Martel's mind and tell what he meant creating the puzzle. I do not think that Martel is a fool but when I'm thinking of the movie, I am recalling this Italian saying: "A fool can ask more questions than seven wise men can answer." Well, I can also ask more questions than seven wise men can answer, but I do not pretend to be smart.Like it or not, to me the story sounds fake, artificial, and cartoon-like. It's a beautiful 3D postcard as flat as it is, not a true spiritual odyssey with trials, ordeals, and temptations.Talking about personal journeys and spiritual growth, I prefer The Odyssey.THE ODYSSEY (1997) Armand Assante, Gretta Scacchi DVDPS If you enjoyed the movie and did not find my review helpful, could you please answer a few questions and explain your point of view?I am a Christian. I believe in omnipotent (all powerful), omniscient (all knowing), and omnipresent (existing everywhere at once, always present) God. You may have different beliefs. Hold on them and try to look at the story without its beautiful visual effects.Suppose, an illegal immigrant's boat sank somewhere in Florida and theillegal immigrant was saved by the US Coast Guard. The guardsmen who areatheist, Jewish, Buddhist, Muslim, and Christian ask the guy, "Whatare you doing here? Are you American?" And the immigrant says, "Chill out,guys! After hearing my story, you will believe in God." And he startstelling them how he survived 227 days after a shipwreck, sailing in the boattogether with a crocodile, a cat, and a dog. He suffered a lot. Thecrocodile ate the dog and the cat. There was no food. To survive, theillegal immigrant had to learn fishing and even tame the beast. Then there was astorm. The immigrant surrendered to God and together with the crocodilereached the US coast where the crocodile escaped.Will the guardsmen believe the story? Of course, not. They will ask theillegal immigrant to stop bulls***ing them and tell them the real story. Sothe illegal immigrant tells them another story, where he sailed in the boattogether with a criminal who killed his two friends, other illegalimmigrants. The guardsmen say, "Another bulls***, but we can't prove whichstory is real." The immigrant says, "It's your problem. But if youprefer the first story, you must know that it goes with God."Questions: Will the atheist guardsmen believe in God after hearing the story? How will the immigrant's story prove them the existence of God? Why does the first story go with God and what's wrong with the second? Why can't the second story prove the existence of God? Will the first story support the beliefs of the Jewish, Muslim, and Christian guardsmen?.. Thanks.

reviewText: Having lived in India for four and a half years, my wife particularly enjoyed the early scenes in "Life of Pi."  Unfortunately, we felt that the movie had several flaws.  The behavior of the tiger, Richard Parker, was not believable, specifically when he inextricably stayed under the canvas for so long.  Also, his inability to claw his way onto the canvas after Pi did not seem realistic.  Why did not Pi succumb to sunburn after days of exposure?  How Pi and Richard Parker survived with so little water was not adequately explained.We thought that far too much time was spent on the lifeboat scenes for no purpose.  On the other hand, the last 10 minutes or so of the movie really tied the loose ends together and got our attention.
summary: Did Not Live up to Hype

reviewText: Visually beautiful (even though the CGI is obvious in any shot that involves motion with any speed to it) & very well acted; still it suffers for its deviations from the novel. There are a number of scenes altered from Martel's work or made up entirely & inserted (clearly in several cases for the aesthetic value of the imagery rather than because they added anything to a story that needed no additions), & others that were key to the story as it was put down on paper which were done away with altogether, leaving gaping holes in the narrative & damaging the ending to a major degree. I couldn't see any reason for these changes, except maybe to get the PG rating since some of the deleted portions were pretty grim, or maybe it was felt that viewers would only go for a cleaned up story with a pat ending; but I was disappointed to see what was done, as it diminished the main character & lessened the impact of his journey both across the Pacific & within himself. They made a good movie out of a great book, when they could have done far better by simply sticking with the source material.
summary: Calvin & Hobbes on the open ocean

reviewText: ...fable I would say.  I looked forward to seeing this film after all the hype (to say nothing of the Academy Awards), so it was inevitable, I suppose, that I was disappointed.The tension between the rational and the ineffable -- science and religion, reason vs. faith, has always been my favorite literary device.  Think "Inherit The Wind", Spencer Tracy version.  The only new insight here is the line "Someone else introduces us to God when we are young" (I paraphrase).  I let that sink in.  True enough.This movie reminded me in some ways of "Cast Away" -- ship/plane-wrecked at sea and lost on a deserted island.  One man has a Bengal tiger, the other a Wilson soccer ball.  Of the two films, "Cast Away" works more cogently for me at illuminating the human condition.  Faith or Fact?  The fork in the road -- the crossroad at the end of "Cast Away", and all the choices which preceeded it.  I'm not being dragged into a discussion of whether or not I "believe in God", or "which story I believe".  Better the mirror held up to see the reflection of a lifetime of choices.The atheist and the person of faith share the same conundrum: neither can speak rationally about the unknowable or metaphysical.  And since no one really knows, we all must wait until our fate meets us.  And therein liveth the fable.ADDENDUM:  I watched this movie a second time in order that I might better connect with the dialogue and narration.  I understand the question (is there a God?), but not the conclusion here: God is in the story.  Life is full of sorrow (polio, shipwrecks, evil people -- which includes the hero here, as he admits in his second version of the story), but also of beauty and joy.  But what we experience as "real" depends on how we tell the story?  And that's where we find God?  Too thin for me.  I do appreciate the author and director for tackling this question, however.  That alone makes this a better-than-average film.ADDENDUM #2:  I bought the 3D BluRay, and I must disagree with the people who say the 3D effects are lacking.  This is the best 3D movie I have purchased yet, including "Avatar", "Hugo", "Bolt", and "John Carter".  The 3D effects are very good on my Sony 3D BD player and 65" Vizio 3D HDTV.  The hummingbird at the opening credits popped right out into the middle of my living room, and I actually got seasick while watching the sinking of the ship.  Really amazing.

reviewText: After finding out what this movie was about, I really did not have much interest in watching it. But then a couple of people whose opinion I respect told me that it was not really about religion and that I should give it a try. I am not sure what they watched, but if this movie is not about religion (or at least about belief in God), then I am superman.The parable used for communicating the greatness of believing in God is actually entertaining, which is why I am giving it 2 stars instead of 1. The animation used for the tiger and in several other scenes is breathtaking. But ultimately, I could not help but feel disappointed in the constant hammering of the idea of God.Of course, it is pretty clear that there is a huge number of people out there who will not find any issues with the concept behind the movie, and as such will have a great time watching it. Since I have to acknowledge that if you are a believer, no matter of which religion, this is probably a very enjoyable film. I understand that. However, for those out there that are similar to me, do not believe in deities and have no interest in watching a film that argues for believing, then this is probably not a good option.
summary: Maybe I am too sensitive, but felt like I was getting religion shoved down my throat

reviewText: If only it were possible to rate LIFE OF PI as a 10-stars video, based on the following:* Plot--This story is as magical as the fairy tales that fascinated us as children* Characters-- Despite their foreignness (to us) as Indians, they have universal appeal as a family of four embarking on a life-changing journey.  The father is strict, knowing that he must teach his sons life's lessons in order to survive.  The mother's compassionate, yet practical.  The older son is more like the father; not so vulnerable to life's travails.  Younger son, Pi, is soulful and his classmates' bullying has helped strengthen his character and his ability to overcome adversity by using his clever intelligence.* Dialogue--Conversations are believable and flow alongside the narration.  While the characters have Indian accents, it is easy to understand what they are saying.* Acting--It is amazing how well the main protagonist, Pi, portrays his role.  It is his first professional acting and his performance is exceptionally good.  Each actor has fulfilled his/her role admirably.* Direction--Ang Lee is known for exploring complex themes.  His adaptation of the novel was outstanding.  He won the Best Director Oscar at the 85th Academy Awards, pitted against the renowned Steven Spielberg.* Sequencing--There are no disjointed cuts in this movie.  With so many locales and scenes, it is almost expected to be choppy in places.  The movie segues seamlessly from one moment to the next.* Sets--Filming is done in India, Canada, on a ship, at sea, a tiny island, and in a hospital room.  The vast majority of it is at sea on a small lifeboat and flimsy raft.  The smallest details are included in each one, adding depth to their locales.* Visual Effects--Done with CGI, it is impossible to discern if the animals are real or digitally portrayed.  Staring into the tiger's eyes is frightening and at times, breathtaking, as Richard Parker's (the tiger's) face assumes almost human emotions.* Color--Simply spectacular!  We watched this on a Samsung TV, giving us an enormous spectrum of color in many shades. Compared to watching other movies and regular programming, the hues of this film were superior to anything else we have seen, except at movie theaters.* Technology--Filmed in HD and 3D, viewers get as realistic a feeling of actually `being there' as possible.  Clarity overall was excellent and made the nighttime sea life and storm scenes `pop'.  The same is true for the island locale.  While we do not have 3D, we think those very scenes and locales must do a magnificent job of enhancing the experience.If you usually watch a movie more than once, then you can count on enjoying LIFE OF PI many times.

reviewText: I want to write this while it's fresh - while the nerve endings in my body are still alive, the tears just drying in my eyes and my heart so full it almost hurts. I just saw 'Life of Pi', my favorite film so far this year and in my Top 10 Films of all time. From the opening credits I knew it was going to be something special ... but I can't remember ever having seen a film that touched me this deeply on the subject of faith. Visually stunning, the film - on the surface a story about a shipwrecked young man trapped alone on a lifeboat with a Bengal tiger - reaches out with such a powerful message of faith and courage and devotion, it left me shaken and weak and realizing just how meaningless much of what we humans worry about really is. Ang Lee deserves the Oscar, Suraj Sharma should have been nominated for playing Pi, and this is one I will be owning the nano-second it comes out on DVD. Just wish my brain didn't feel so scrambled, so I could write a more worthy review of this incredibly beautiful piece of art.
summary: Perfection on film, thanks to Ang Lee and Suraj Sharma
